Alternaria leaf spot disease spreads more in wet weather in Ramtil plants.  On the onset of this disease, oval brown spots are formed on the leaves of the plant.  In the event of severe disease, the size of the spots increases.  Due to which the leaves of the plant are destroyed and fall.  To prevent this disease, appropriate amount of thiram or zineb should be sprayed on the plants.

Bhuva pillu

Bhu Pillu disease is an insect-borne disease.  Sundi of this disease eats the newly formed leaves on the plant.  Due to which the plant stops growing.  Weeping is found on the skin of this disease.  To prevent this disease, appropriate amount of Nuwan medicine or imidalkoprid should be sprayed on the plants.  Apart from this, using neem oil and surf solution is also beneficial.

Ramtil's Worm

Worms of Ramtil eat the leaves of the plant and harm them.  Due to which the plant stops growing.  The worm of this disease is green in color.  On which purple stripes are found.  For prevention of this disease in Ramtil plants, when the disease appears, the appropriate amount of trizophase should be sprayed twice in 10 days interval.

Powdery mildew

Churni fungal disease is also known as Bhubhtiya disease.  In plants, the disease spreads due to fungi.  In the beginning of this disease, white colored powder gets deposited on the leaves of the plant, all the leaves of the plant appear white when the disease progresses.  Due to which the plant is unable to perform photosynthesis.  And soon they are destroyed by drying.  For prevention of this disease, spraying of appropriate amount of M-45 or soluble sulfur on the plants should be done on the plants.  Apart from this, the diseased plants should be removed from the field and destroyed.

Sarcospora Foil Stain

In Ramatil plants, the effect of this disease is seen during the development of plants.  In the beginning of this disease, small brown spots are formed on the leaves of the plants.  Whose size increases with the increase of disease on plants.  Whose leaves fall prematurely and get destroyed.  And the growth of plants stops.  For the prevention of this disease, seed should be treated with thyroid before transplanting.  Also, in case of disease in standing crop, appropriate amount of hexaconazole should be sprayed on the plants.

entry.title: How to cultivated rice
entry.content:
Paddy (rice) is cultivated extensively in India after maize.  Paddy is most commonly used in food.  People boil paddy, make khichdi and use it as flour.  Paddy remains the main fertilizer crop in most states of India.  After China, India is the largest producer of paddy.  Paddy crop is grown in Kharif season.




Paddy (rice) crop needs water the most.  Due to this, it is cultivated in soil with high water holding capacity.  It does not require much temperature for cultivation.  PH of land for paddy cultivation  Value should not be too high.  Paddy is not planted as a seed in the field and is planted as a plant.  Paddy cultivation is a hard-earned crop.If you also want to cultivate paddy, then today we are going to give you complete information about its cultivation.

Suitable soil

Smooth black soils are best suited for paddy cultivation.  Because smooth soil has more water holding capacity.  This type of soil is filled with water for several days after watering it.  In India, it is cultivated in most states of North to South India.  PH of land for paddy cultivation  The value should be from 5.5 to 6.5.  Although less and more P.H.  The treated land is being cultivated in them as well.

Climate and temperature

Areas with both hot and subtropical climate are suitable for paddy cultivation.  In India, it is cultivated during the Kharif season.  Paddy cultivation is mostly done in irrigated areas.  More rain is required for its cultivation.  It is necessary to have 100 mm of rain for paddy cultivation.  Irrigation has to be done more when there is less rain

Normal temperature is required for a paddy plant.  But it also tolerates maximum 35 degree temperature.  Its plant gives good yield at normal temperature, and the plant also grows well.

Advanced varieties

Many varieties of paddy are available in the market.  Those have been divided into several species based on ripening time and land conditions.

Early maturing species

Varieties of this species are prepared by cooking very soon.  They are grown as early varieties.

Narendra-118

It takes 85 to 90 days to cook this variety of paddy.  This variety has been prepared for less irrigated places.  Its grain is long, thin and white in color.  The production per hectare of this variety is found from 45 to 50 quintals.  65 to 70 percent of rice is obtained from this type of paddy.

Manhar

The grains of this variety of paddy are thin, long and white in color.  From which up to 70 percent rice is obtained.  It takes about 100 days to cook this type of plant.  Scorching disease is not found on this type of plants.  The yield of this variety is found to be around 50 quintals.

Malaviya Paddy - 917

This variety of paddy plant is ripened in 135 days.  Its grains are small and fragrant.  This variety has been prepared by Kashi Hindu University.  The yield per hectare is found to be 55 to 60 quintals.  Strong storms and storms have no effect on this variety.

Medium ripening species

Varieties of this species take a little longer to ripen quickly.  But their yield is more.

Narendra-359

Plants of this type do not get scorching disease.  Bali is especially grown in all the rings of its plant.  Plants of this variety are ripe and ready in 130 to 135 days.  The yield per hectare is 60 to 65 quintals.  Up to 72 percent rice is obtained from this variety of paddy.  Whose size is big, thick and color is light white.

Sita

This type of paddy is ready to ripen in about 130 days.  Which is medium sized.  Its color is white.  The yield of this variety is found to be around 50 quintals.

Malaviya Paddy-1

It takes about 125 days to cook this type of paddy.  Its grains are thin and white.  The yield per hectare is found to be 55 to 60 quintals.  Up to 70 percent of rice is obtained from this variety of paddy.

Sun-52

This variety of paddy is not prone to scorching disease.  70 percent rice can be obtained from this type of paddy.  It takes about 135 days for its plant to be cooked and prepared.  Its grain is long and medium thickness.  Its yield per hectare is around 60 quintals.

Late maturing species

Varieties of this species are cooked and prepared over a long period of time.  And their yield is also found to be normal.

Mussoorie

It takes about 150 days to cook this variety of plants.  The grain of this type of paddy is medium size and light white.  This variety can also be grown in 30 cm deep water.  Its yield per hectare is found to be around 30 to 40 quintals.  Which gives rice up to 70 percent.

Samba Mehsuri

It takes 155 days to cook this variety of paddy.  Plants of this variety are dwarf-shaped.  From which paddy is obtained up to 60 quintals in one hectare.  In which the quantity of rice is found up to 70 percent.  The rice of this variety is small, thin and white in color.

Aromatic Paddy Species

Varieties of this species are also known as hybrid varieties.  This variety is designed for quicker and higher yields.

Oysters

Yield per hectare of this variety of paddy is found around 40 quintals.  Its plants are ripe and ready in about 125 days.  Plants of this type do not suffer scorching and gum disease.  Up to 65 percent of rice is obtained from this variety of paddy.  Which are found thin and tall in shape.  Their color is white.

Haryana Basmati-1

Plants of this variety are ripe and ready in 140 days.  Whose yield per hectare is found around 45 quintals.  65 to 70 percent rice can be obtained from this variety of paddy.  Whose size is thin.  Green pudding disease is not used on this type of paddy.

Taravadi Basmati

Plants of this variety are ripe and ready in 140 to 150 days.  Their yield per hectare is found to be around 30 quintals.  Many types of pests and diseases are not available on this variety.  Up to 68 percent rice can be obtained from this variety of paddy, which is thin, long and fragrant.

Pusa RH-10

This variety is considered the first hybrid variety of the whole world.  The grain of this variety of paddy is highly fragrant, long and thin.  It takes about 120 days to prepare this variety.  The yield per hectare of this variety is found around 65 quintals.

Tusker

Varieties of this species have been prepared to give more and quick yield in the barren Usri land.  Plants of this type require less water.

Narendra Osar - 2 and 3

It takes about 130 days to cook this variety of paddy.  A yield of 50 quintals per hectare can be obtained from this variety of plants.  Up to 62 percent of grains are obtained from this type of paddy.  Whose color is light white and in shape it is found long and round.  Brown spots and scorching disease are not found on this type of plant.

CSR 13-13

It takes about 120 days to cook this variety of paddy.  The yield per hectare of this variety is found to be 50 to 60 quintals.  Up to 60 percent of grains can be obtained from this type of paddy.  Which are thin and tall in shape.  Their color is found to be white.

Osar Paddy-1

This variety of paddy is cooked in 140 to 150 days.  The yield per hectare of this variety is found from 45 to 50 quintals.  Up to 65 percent grains can be obtained from this variety of paddy.  Its grains are small, thick and white in color.

For flooded area

Varieties of this species of paddy have been prepared for high flooding areas during the rains.  Its plants need more water.

Swarna Sav-1

It takes 140 to 150 days to cook this variety of paddy.  The yield per hectare of this variety is found to be around 40 quintals.  Up to 75 percent grains can be obtained from this variety of paddy.  Its grains are small, thin and white in color.

Water fund

The plant of this variety of paddy is very long.  Which grows like a lotus in water.  On which there are many types of diseases also.  Plants of this type take 180 days to cook and prepare.  65 to 70 percent of the grains can be obtained from this variety of paddy.  Its grain is curvy, light and peppery.  Which is light red.

Madhukar

This variety of paddy is grown in areas with occasional floods.  Plants of this variety are ready to ripen in 150 days.  Their yield per hectare is found in 30 to 40 quintals.  From which up to 65 percent grains are obtained.  Its grains are small, thick and white in color.

Field plowing

Initially, for paddy cultivation, make two to three deep plowing of the field and mediate it.  Do this preparation of the field before the rainy season, so that the rain water in the field gets filled up.  If there is no rain, the field should be filled with water  After that, two to three good plowing should be done with a soil-plowing plow in a water-filled land.  This creates mud in the soil.  In which paddy is planted.

Nursery preparation

Paddy seeds are not directly grown in the field.  The seed is first prepared in the nursery.  After that, plant his seedlings in the field.  Before growing the seed in the nursery, soak it in streptomycin sulfate or planto mycin solution for one night.  Due to which there is no scorching disease in the plant.  And if the problem of scorching is not in the area, the seeds should be sown by treating them with carbendazim or thiram.

The seeds should be soaked in water one night before growing in the nursery.  This brings seedlings to the seed.  The seedlings are sprinkled in the beds.  Sprinkle the trichoderma in the seed after 10 days of growing the seed.  And to prevent Khaira disease, after 15 days, sprinkle zinc sulphate and quenched lime in appropriate quantity in the beds.

Paddy seeds require more water.  Therefore, keep the quantity of water in the beds appropriate.  Paddy seeds are ready in about one to one and a half months.  After that, remove it from the beds and plant it in the fields.  But before removing the plant from the bed, the bed should be filled with water so that it is easy to remove the plant, and the plant is not spoiled.

Plant planting method and time

Farmer brothers plant paddy plants both by hand and machine.  But currently Madagascar method is being used the most.  In this method, paddy seedlings are planted by hand in the field.  This method is also known as Sri Vidhi.  In this method, paddy is planted at a distance of 15 cm in rows.  Also keep a distance of 15 cm between the two lines.  In one place, two to three plants of paddy are planted together.  By this method, the yield of paddy is high.  In a simple way, paddy is planted at a distance of 10 cm.  Due to which the plant also looks more and yields are also normal.

Sowing of paddy should be done about one week before the arrival of monsoon.  Because the plant sprouts well till the monsoon arrives.  Due to which more water is filled in the field during the monsoon, the plant develops well.  The month of June is most suitable for planting paddy.

Plant irrigation

Paddy plant needs more water.  For this reason, irrigation should be done at the appropriate time of its plant.  During the paddy irrigation, some such conditions of the plants come when the plant needs water the most.  After planting the plant in the field, the fields should be filled with water when the buds explode, the earrings grow, the flowers bloom and the earrings are filled.  Because if there is no water in the field at these times, the plant will neither grow well nor will the yield be good.

The paddy plant needs about 15 to 20 irrigations.  Whenever the water stops appearing in the field and the upper ground starts drying up, then the plants should be watered.

Amount of fertilizer

Paddy plants need more fertilizer.  For this, at the time of plowing, about 12 vehicles of cow dung fertilizer should be applied per acre.  Put the manure in the field and mix it well in the soil.  Also, 25 to 30 kg of nitrogen, 40 kg of phosphorus and 40 kg of potash per hectare should be planted at the time of last plowing before planting paddy in the field.  After that 30 to 40 kg of nitrogen should be given along with irrigation of the plants at the time of formation of buds.  And about 20 kg of nitrogen should be given to the plants before planting seeds in Bali.

weed control

Weed causes more damage in paddy crop.  In paddy plants, weed control can be done both by weeding and chemically.  For simple weed control, weeding should be done in the field by weeding out the field.

About 20 to 25 days after transplanting of paddy, its first procession should be done.  After that the second hoeing should be done about 20 days after the first hoeing.  In this way it is good to do two to three pudding of paddy.  Because two to three pudding of the paddy plant produces more quantity of buds from the ground.  Which gives higher yield.

For chemical control of weeds, two to three days after planting the plant in the field, Bispribac sodium 10 percent SC  Or Pretilachlor 30 percent EC should be sprayed in the field.

Diseases in plants and their prevention

Disease in paddy plants is more than temperature and climate related factors.  Because of which paddy diseases have been divided into three parts based on their factors.

Fungal disease

Fungi causes damage to plants from both roots and leaves.

Stem melting

In plants, this disease is caused by a fungus called Saclerotinia sucralcium.  On the onset of this disease, brown spots start forming on the plants.  Which later appear as white colored fungi.  Gradually, this disease is seen on the entire plant.  Due to which the plant gets dried and destroyed.  Carbendazim should be sprayed on the plants to prevent this disease.

Foliar melting

The onset of this disease causes a lot of loss in yield.  Plant growth stops due to this disease.  Its effect is seen on newly growing branches and buds.  If the earrings are not formed in the plant due to this disease, grains are not formed in them.  For the prevention of this disease, spraying of benlet or deconil should be done at the appropriate time.

Brown spots

Brown spots disease is seen on the soft parts of the plant.  Small, round and brown spots appear on the leaves due to this disease.  Whose inner color appears yellow.  All these small spots slowly get together to form a large size.  Earrings are not formed in plants due to this disease.  To prevent this disease, 10 ppm of magnesium sulfate in the roots of plants.  And 2.5 ppm of ferric chloride.  Solution should be poured.  Apart from this, while sowing the seeds, the seeds should be treated with agrosan or thiram and grown in the field.

Khaira

The effect of this disease is seen on the husbands of the plants.  Which seems due to lack of zinc in the plant.  On the onset of this disease, the color of the leaves of the plant starts appearing yellow.  After which the leaves are dried and destroyed.  For the prevention of this disease, spraying of zinc sulphate in the field should be done at the time of last plowing.

Bacterial disease

Bacterial diseases are caused by bacteria in plants.

Leaf pan

In plants, symptoms of this disease are seen on the leaves.  On the leaves, this disease starts from the beginning and progresses downwards.  Due to which the color of leaves starts becoming yellow.  And she starts leaning down.  On applying this disease, proper amount of blitax and agramycin should be sprayed on the plant

Leaf line

On the onset of this disease, yellowish green color lines are formed on the leaves.  Its bacterium is yellow and white in color like pearl.  Which is found on both of the leaves.  Due to this disease, the color of the veins of the leaves starts to appear yellow and after a few days the leaves are dried and destroyed.  For the prevention of this disease, spraying of agrimycin or streptocycline should be done on the plants.

Virus borne

Virus-borne diseases cause more damage to plants.  Which reduces the yield.

Exponential growth

On the onset of this disease, the plant appears dwarf even after the entire period.  Due to this disease, the color of leaves starts appearing yellow from below.  Because of this disease, earrings do not grow in the plant and if they grow, then grains do not form in them.  For prevention of this disease, advanced seeds should be grown.

Tungro

On the onset of this disease, the color of the leaves of the plant starts appearing yellow.  And the shape of the plant remains dwarf.  On which small size earrings come out.  And in earrings, grains are found in very small amounts.  For the prevention of this disease, monocrotophos 36 E.C., carberil 50 w.  P. or Phosphamidon 85 W.  Sc  Should be sprinkled

Paddy harvesting and mowing

The paddy plant is ripe and ready in 100 to 150 days.  The plant gets ready for harvesting after one month of planting on each plant.  During this time the plant appears yellow.  When there is 20 percent moisture in the paddy seeds, then they should be cut.

After cutting, its culverts are dried in the sun for a few days and their rigging is done through a machine.  The straw made from it is used in the eating of animals.  Whereas some small farmer brothers do it with drums with their hands.  Its husk is also used to protect many things from breaking and deteriorating during transportation.

Yields and benefits

The average yield per hectare of different varieties of paddy is found to be 50 to 70 quintals per hectare.  And the market price of paddy is found around four thousand per quintal.  With which farmer brothers can earn from two to three lakhs at a time.

entry.title: Complete information on how to cultivate jowar
entry.content:
Jowar is cultivated as coarse cereal crop and green fodder.  All parts of jowar are used as animal feed.  Apart from this, people also use its donations in some places.  Khichdi and chapati are made from its seeds.Jowar cultivation can be done in both irrigated and non-irrigated places.  Jowar is cultivated in India along with kharif crops.  Its plants can be of 10 to 12 feet in length.  Which can be cut many times in green form.  Its plant does not need any special temperature.  Most farmer brothers cultivate it as green fodder only.  But some farmers grow it commercially.

If you are also planning to cultivate it, then today we are going to give you complete information about its cultivation.


Suitable soil

Jowar can be cultivated in any kind of soil.  But to get higher yield, it should be grown in smooth soils with proper drainage.  PH of land for its cultivation  Values must be between 5 and 7.

Climate and temperature

Jowar is cultivated along with kharif crops.  During this period, they grow well when they are properly irrigated in the summer season.  Its plants need more general rain.  If you do more irrigation of your plants during the hot summer season, the effect of fast heat is not seen on its plants.  And plants grow well.

Jowar seeds require normal temperature at the time of germination.  After that, 25 to 30 degree temperature is suitable for the plants to grow.  But its fully grown plants grow easily even at 45 degree temperature.

Advanced varieties

There are many advanced varieties of sorghum that have been prepared for their high production and frequent harvesting.

Pusa Chari 23

Plants of this variety are thin, tall and less juicy.  Whose taste is less sweet.  Its plants of this variety are known to harvest more in less time.  Its plants yield green fodder and around 160 to 180 kintal dry fodder per hectare.  It is cultivated mainly for green fodder only.

CSB  13

Plants of this variety of sorghum are prepared by ripening around 110 days.  The height of its plants is found between 10 and 15 feet.  This variety of sorghum can be grown for both green fodder and charcoal.  The seeds can be obtained after two harvesting of its seeds early transplanting.  Yield per hectare of this variety is found in the range of 15 to 20 kW.  While its yield as dry fodder is found around 100 kW.

Ssg  593

This variety of jowar is grown for green fodder.  The production per hectare of its plants in the form of green fodder is found around 600 to 700 kwh.  Its plants have been prepared for frequent harvesting.  Plants of this variety are thin, tall and with less juice.  More than 150 kintal is received as dry fodder from this variety of plants.  Many types of kit-borne diseases are not seen on this type of plants.

Csh 16

It is a hybrid of jowar.  Whose plants are ready to ripen in about 110 days after planting.  The production per hectare of this variety of plants is found to be from 30 to 40 quintals.  Around 90 kintal is obtained from this variety of plants as dry fodder.  Plants of this variety are found to be of normal height.

MP.  Fodder

This variety of jowar is also grown mainly for green fodder.  But by planting it early, it can be cultivated for both green fodder and grains.  Plants of this variety are prepared after planting seeds around 120 days.  Flowers on its plant begin to form after about 70 days of planting.  From this variety of plants, green fodder can be obtained around 500 kW and hectare around 18 kW.

P.C.H.  106

This variety of jowar is grown for green fodder.  On this type of plant, flowers begin to form 50 to 60 days after transplanting seeds.  Plants of this variety appear to be tall with moderate thickness.  In which the quantity of juice is normally found less.  Up to 800 quintals of green fodder can be obtained from this variety of plants.  Its plants can be harvested many times.

Green gold

This variety of jowar can be grown in most of the states around Punjab.  Production of green fodder per hectare of this variety of plants is found around 650 kiwtl.  Plants of this variety can give three to four cuttings.  6 to 8 buds grow from one plant.  Plants of this variety are thin, tall and less juicy.

Field preparation

Initially, for the cultivation of jowar, plow two to three slopes of the field and put appropriate amount of cow dung in it.  After that, plow the field again and mix the manure in the soil.  After mixing the fertilizer in the soil, leave it in the field and grow it  After three to four days of growing, when the fields start to dry, then make the soil of the field brittle by running a rotavator.  After that, make it flat by driving the field in the field.  Jowar is planted in flat fields.

Seed Transplant Method and Time

Jowar seeds are planted by both drill and sprinkler methods.  Before planting these seeds, they should be treated with appropriate amount of carbendazim or the government certified seeds should be grown.  As a production of jowar seeds, 12 to 15 kg of seed per hectare is sufficient.  But for planting as green fodder, around 30 kg of seed is required.

During planting by spraying method, farmers make two light plowing of the field through cultivators by spraying its seeds in the field.  When planting seeds by sprinkling method, plowing the field with light patta behind the plows.  Due to which the seed mixes well in the soil.  While its seeds are planted in rows through drill.  A fit distance is kept between each rows when planting in rows.  Whereas the distance between the seeds in the row should be around 5 centimeters.  During both of these methods, its seeds should be grown three to four centimeters below ground during transplanting.  This results in good germination of seeds.

Jowar seeds are planted with kharif crops.  But while cultivating it as green fodder, it is good to grow it in the last April or early May before the rainy season.  During this time sowing of sorghum can be harvested many times.  Whereas, to cultivate as Dano, it should be grown with the first rains with millet.

Irrigation of plants

When sorghum is cultivated as its yield, there is a general need for irrigation.  During this time, its plants need three to four irrigations.  Whereas, when cultivated as green fodder, its plants require more irrigation.  On cultivation as green fodder, its plants should be irrigated at intervals of three to four days.  With this, plants grow well.  And the plant is soon ready for harvesting.

Amount of fertilizer

There is a general need for fertilizer in jowar cultivation.  But fertilizer is needed for farming as green fodder.  Initially, for the cultivation of jowar, at the time of plowing of the field, put about 10 cartons of old cow dung in the field and mix it in the soil.  In addition to organic manure, a sack D.A.P.  Sprinkle the amount in the field per hectare.  Apart from this, on cultivation as green fodder, after every harvesting of its plants, 20 to 25 kg of urea per hectare should be sprayed in the field.

weed control

When sorghum is cultivated as green fodder, its plants do not require weed control.  But if we cultivate it as weed, weed control should be done in its plants.  In jowar cultivation, weed control is done both by natural and chemical methods.  For the weed control by chemical methods, the appropriate amount of atrazine should be sprayed immediately after transplanting its seeds.  For natural weed control, seedlings should be planted once after 20 to 25 days after transplanting its seeds.  There is a lot of thickness of its plants.

Plant diseases and their prevention

Many types of diseases are seen in sorghum plants.  Which causes a lot of damage to its yields and plants.  Yield losses can be avoided by taking care of those who have proper time.

Scorching leaf

The effect of leaf scorching disease in sorghum plants is seen due to weather changes and water filler.  In the beginning of this disease, the leaves of plants start to appear yellow.  Which slowly starts to dry from the ends.  The entire plant gets destroyed when the disease progresses.  To prevent this disease, do not let the waterlogging happen in the field.

Stem borer

The effect of stem borer in sorghum plants can be seen anytime during the growth of plants after germination.  It is an insect-borne disease on sorghum plants.  Sundi of this disease pierces the trunk of plants and destroys it from inside.  Due to which the plant stops growing.  And soon dries up and perishes.  To prevent this disease, appropriate amount of carbofuron should be sprayed on its plants twice in 10 days interval.

Locust attack

The attack of locusts on its plants is seen more during the ripening of the crop.  Locusts affect the growth of plants by eating the leaves of its plant.  Due to which the difference is seen in the yield of the plant.  For prevention of this disease, proper amount of granulated forage should be sprayed in the field.

Pyrilla

This is an insect-borne disease in sorghum plants.  Pests of this disease suck the soft parts of plants and affect their growth.  Due to which the plant stops growing.  On the onset of this disease, the plant is soon dried up and destroyed.  For prevention of this disease, spraying of appropriate amount of monocrotophos or profenophos should be done on the plants.

White braided

The effect of white braided insect in sorghum plants can be seen anytime after the plants germinate.  Pests of this disease cut the roots of sorghum plants and cause more damage.  Due to which the plant is soon dried and destroyed.  To prevent this disease, chloropyriphos should be applied to the roots of the plants at the time of rain.  Apart from this, sprinkling of appropriate amount of forage should be done at the time of plowing of the field.

Root thawing

In tidal plants, the effect of root thawing disease can be seen at any time.  Due to the effect of this disease on plants, their growth stops.  And the leaves start turning yellow after turning.  As the disease progresses, the entire plant turns yellow and perishes.  For prevention of this disease, proper amount of theram or captan should be sprayed on the plants.

Tide mite

This is an insect disease that occurs in sorghum plants.  Which causes more damage to leaves of plants.  Pests of this disease form webs on the lower surface of the leaves of plants.  Those who suck the juice of its leaves.  Due to which the leaves start appearing red.  To prevent this disease, neem oil should be sprayed on the plants.

Harvesting and embroidery

Jowar plants are ready for harvesting after about 110 days of planting.  During this, the amount of moisture in its seeds decreases.  And the leaves of the plant start drying up.  During this time the plants should be harvested.  Jowar plants are harvested twice.

First its plants are cut off from the ground surface and separated.  After that, its granular part is cut from the plants and separated.  After that the donated parts are collected in the field and left to dry for a few days.  And when the grains are dried, they are removed with the help of a machine and separated.

Yields and benefits

Average yield per hectare of different varieties of sorghum plants is found up to 25 kW.  Whereas, dry fodder from its plants receives from 100 to 150 kW.  The market price of its donations is found to be around 2.5 thousand rupees per quintal.  According to which the farmer brother earns around 60 thousand from one hectare at a time.

link.title: Complete information on how to cultivate jowar

entry.title: How to cultivate orange - complete information
entry.content:
Oranges are cultivated as juicy fruits.  Its fruits are counted in lemon class fruits.  Santre is the most grown in India after banana and mango.  Oranges are mainly used in food.  It is eaten as a food by peeling and taking out juice.  Drinking orange juice has many beneficial benefits.  Its juice cools the body and relieves fatigue and stress.  Its fruit is also beneficial in many diseases.  Jams and jellies are made from orange juice.



Orange cultivation

Dry climate is required for orange cultivation.  Its plants do not require much rain to grow.  In India, it is cultivated mainly in Rajasthan, Himachal Pradesh, Gujarat, Maharashtra, Punjab, Haryana and Uttar Pradesh.  Summer is required to ripen its fruits.  Its plants start yielding three to four years after planting in the field.

If you are also planning to cultivate it, then today we are going to give you complete information about its cultivation.

Suitable soil

Waterlogged land of orange cultivation is not suitable.  Its plants give good yield in light loam soils with proper drainage.  PH of land for its cultivation  Values must be between 6.5 to 8.

Climate and temperature

Dry and warm climate is suitable for orange cultivation.  Its plants do not need much rain.  Its plants are more affected during the season of the century.  And frost in winter is harmful for its cultivation.  Light heat is more suitable for its cultivation.  Its fruits need sunlight to ripen.

For its cultivation, initially the temperature between 20 to 25 degrees is appropriate during planting of the plants.  After that, plants need a temperature around 30 degrees to grow.  A minimum temperature of 10 in winter and a maximum of 35 degrees in summer is suitable for its cultivation.

Advanced varieties

There are many different varieties of orange plants present in the market.  Those have been prepared on the basis of their quality and yield.

Sikkim

This variety of orange is also known as Khasi.  Plants of this variety are mostly grown in eastern India.  The branches of this type of plant are thorny and have more leaves.  The fruits grown on this type of plant have soft surface.  Whose colors appear slightly pale yellow.  A plant of this variety yields around 80 kg at a time.  The quantity of seeds is found in its fruits.

Coorg

Plants of this variety are straight and deep.  From which one plant receives 80 to 100 kg of fruits at a time.  The fruits of this variety are easily peeled.  Inside which buds are drunk around 10.  In which the maximum quantity of seeds is found.  The fruits of this variety are ripened and prepared in the month of February.

Nagpuri

Advanced variety

This is a high yielding variety of oranges.  The fruits of which are liked all over India.  Its plants start yielding after four years of planting in the field.  From which 120 to 150 kg of fruits can be obtained at one time from a fully grown plant.  The fruits of this variety appear yellow after ripening.  About 10 to 12 buds are found in its fruit.  In which the quantity of juice is high.

Kinnu

This is a hybrid of orange.  Which has been prepared by hybridization of king and willow leaf.  The skin of this type of fruit is slightly thick.  The fruits of this variety are more juicy.  Because of this, the fruits of this type have more commercial value.  Around 100 kg of fruits can be obtained from one plant at a time.  The color of its fruit appears yellow.  The flowers, which bloom and ripen in January or February.

Kinnu Nagpur Seedless

This variety of orange has been prepared in the Center of Excellence for Citrus.  Which has been prepared by hybridization of foreign plants.  Plants of this variety are known to give higher yields, like Nagpuri oranges.  This type of fruit does not contain seeds.  The fruits of which appear yellow after ripening.

Apart from these, there are many other varieties.  Which are being grown in many places depending on their yield.  There are many saree varieties like Clementine, Daisy, Jaffa, Washington Naval Orange, Kara, Darjeeling, Sumithra, Nagar, Butwal and Danakya.

Field preparation

Orange plants give yield for many years after planting once.  For its cultivation, remove the remnants of old crops present in the field and deep plowing the field.  After that, plow two to three fine slopes through the cultivator in the field.  After plowing, plow the field and make it flat.

After leveling the field, prepare pits in rows leaving a distance of 15 to 18 feet in it.  While preparing the pits, their size should be one meter wide and one meter deep.  After preparing the pits, mix the appropriate amount of old cow dung in the soil and fill it in the pits and deep-irrigate them.  After irrigation, cover the pits through the casserole.

Plant preparation

Before planting orange plants in the field, their seedlings are prepared in the nursery.  For this, leave the orange seeds in the ash to dry.  After the seeds are dry, they are filled with soil in the nursery and applied in polythene bangs prepared.  Two to three seeds should be grown in each bag.  It takes two to three weeks for its seeds to germinate.

After the seeds have germinated, destroy the weak plants and keep the plants growing uniformly.  After that, when the plants are about two feet in height, then the cuttings are prepared through the technique of planting saplings.  You can get more information about pen preparation methods from this article.

Apart from this, farmers can buy its saplings from any nursery registered by the brother government.  Due to which the time of the farmer brothers is saved a lot.  And they start getting yield soon.  But while buying plants from any nursery, keep in mind that always buy only two-branch and broad-leaved plants.  And the plant should be at least two years old.

Plant planting method and time

After the orange plants are ready, they are planted in the pits prepared in the field.  Before planting the saplings in the pits, with the help of khurpi in the pits prepared, we prepare another small pit.  In this prepared small pit, remove the polythene of the plant and apply it.  After that, press the plant thoroughly with soil from all sides.

Orange plants should be grown in the field during the rainy season.  Because during this time the plant does not even need water.  And the weather also gets favorable for the plant to grow.  Apart from this, where there is proper arrangement of water, its plants can also be planted in the month of February.

Irrigation of plants

Orange plants require more irrigation in the beginning.  For this, water should be given to the plant in appropriate quantity.  Its plants should be watered immediately after planting in the field.  After that the plants should be watered once a week in the summer season.  And in winter season, its plants should be watered in a month's time.  When the plant is fully grown then it only needs four to five irrigations a year.  Which is mainly done at the time of blooming flowers on the plant.  Due to which fruits are made well.

Amount of fertilizer

Orange plant needs a lot of fertilizer.  For this, before preparing the plants in the field, while preparing the pits, mix 20 to 25 kg old dung manure in the soil and fill it in the pits.  After that, when the plant becomes three years old, then one kg of NPK as chemical fertilizer along with cow dung manure.  The amount should be given to the plants thrice a year.  As the plant grows.  In the same way, the amount of fertilizer should be increased.  This makes the plant grow well.

weed control

Weed control in orange plants should be done by kneading in the natural way.  For this, the first weeding of plants should be done about 20 to 25 days after transplanting.  After that whenever weeds are seen in the plant, only then the plants should be weeded, due to which the roots of the plants also get good amount of air.  And the plant also grows well.  Apart from this, if the remaining land between the plants in the field is empty, then it should be plowed after it is dry after the rainy season.  This causes more weeds in the field to take birth.

Plant care

It is important to take care of orange plants.  For this, after planting the plant in the field, it should be protected from the sun and frost in the beginning.  After that, when the plant is fully ready and starts giving fruits, then after cutting of the fruits all the branches which appear dry should be cut.  Apart from this, if there is any branch suffering from disease, then it should also be cut and separated.  With this, new branches are born in the plant.  Which gives higher yields from the plant.

Additional earnings

Orange plants start yielding after four years of planting in the field.  During this time, the farmer brother can earn a good income by growing vegetable crops that are ready to be grown in his fields.  Due to this, the farmers do not have to face the financial problems in the beginning.

Plant diseases and their prevention

Many types of diseases are seen in the orange plant.  Which causes a lot of damage to its plants and fruits.  By saving the plants from these diseases, farmer brothers can get good yield.

Citrus canker disease

This disease is seen on the orange plants during the rainy season.  The disease starts with yellow spots.  But as the disease progresses, its shape resembles that of ulcers.  Whose color appears light brown.  This disease is seen only on fruits on plants.  Due to which the market price of fruits is very less.  To prevent this disease, appropriate amount of streptocycline or blitox should be sprayed on the plants.

Anthracnose

This disease that occurs on the orange plant is also known as die back.  On the onset of this disease, the branches of the plant start drying up and down.  Due to which the leaves of the plant become yellow and dry.  When this disease occurs on the plant, cut those branches and remove them.  And plants should be sprayed with appropriate amount of carbondazim.  And the Bordeaux mixture should be coated at the end of the cut branches.

espreads due to kit.  Pests of this disease suck the leaves of the plant and harm them.  On applying this disease, proper amount of pyrethroids should be sprayed on the plants.

Citrus silla

This disease on the orange plant is also a kit-borne disease.  The kits of this disease suck the juice of the leaves of the plant and emit a fluid.  Due to which the leaf of the plant and the skin of the fruit burns.  If this disease occurs, sprinkle monocrotophos on the plants.  And the diseased leaves, fruits and branches should be cut and removed.

Fruit harvesting

Orange fruits are harvested from January to March.  During this time, when the color of fruits starts to appear yellow and attractive, then they should be cut apart with the stalks.  This makes the fruits appear fresh for longer.  After tucking the fruits, tail them with clean cloth and dry them in shady places.  After that, fill the fruits in a ventilated box with hay.  After that the box is closed and sent to market.

Yields and benefits

The yield from the orange plant depends on the care of the plant.  Higher yield can be obtained from plants by taking good care of them.  An average yield of 100 to 150 kg can be obtained from a fully grown plant of different varieties of oranges.  Whereas in an acre field more than 100 plants can be planted.  Whose total yield is obtained from 10000 to 15000 kg at a time.  Whose wholesale price in the market is found to be around 10 to 30 rupees per kg.  Whom the farmer brother can easily earn from one acre to two lakhs at a time.

link.title: How to cultivate orange - complete information

entry.title: How to cultivate flowers
entry.content:
Flowers have been cultivated in India since ancient times, but then they were produced only for private use.  Generally flowers were planted by people in the courtyard of their home, which were also used in performing religious rituals etc.  But since presently both the importance and use of flowers have increased in human life, so today Flower Farming Yaniki flowers are cultivated by people for earning commercially.  It is meant to say that the process of cultivating flowers commercially has started from last few years.  Since the bouquets of flowers have started to be given as gifts in the current lifestyle, the production of roses, lotus, tuberose and carnations etc. is also increasing continuously in the country.  At present, flowers are used globally for many events such as anniversaries, weddings, birthdays, anniversaries of the institute, decorating offices, decorating homes, religious activities, etc.  This is the reason that the demand for these flowers remains not only in the domestic market but also in the international markets.


Scenario of flower farming in India

As we have also mentioned in the above sentences that flower farming started commercially in India only a few years.  But now the production of flowers in India is increasing continuously because there are many areas in India whose climate is suitable for the cultivation of delicate and soft flowers.  According to a report of the National Horticulture Board published in the year 2012, flowers were being cultivated in about 232.74 thousand hectares of land in the country.  In which about 7778 million tons of flowers were being produced.  Although floriculture is being practiced commercially in not one but several states in India, West Bengal ranks first in this race with 32% flower production.  So Karnataka is second with 12%, Maharashtra is third with 10%.  Many types of flowers such as roses, marigold, carnations, glades, tuberose, etc. are produced in India.  According to a data, in the financial year 2013-14, India exported flowers worth about Rs 456 crore.  The main sellers or importers of India's flowers have been the United Arab Emirates, Japan, Canada, Germany, USA, UK, Netherlands etc.  Therefore, it can be said that through Flower Farming, the entrepreneur can not only sell the product produced by him in the domestic market but there is a good demand for flowers in the international markets as well.

Importance of cultivating flowers

See, it is very important to make it clear here that flowers are used not only in our country but in the whole world.  This is the reason that more than 140 countries globally are associated with the business of floriculture.  Since no business is confined to the borders of the country at present, entrepreneurs can earn by selling their products in foreign markets.  Although we have already told that flower farming is not new in India, but it is relatively new in India to cultivate it by building poly houses etc. on a commercial level.  Since India lacks various agro-climatic and talent-rich human resources, this is the reason that such new routes are being paved in the field of floriculture, which have not yet been exploited.  Presently, since trade is done globally, movement of products like flowers is possible with freedom all over the world.  As a consumer of flowers in the world, America is the first, Japan is the second place where flowers worth ten billion dollars and seven billion dollars respectively are consumed in a year.  Since India has a tropical climate and people are growing towards tropical flowers, it is a good time for India to take advantage of this opportunity.

Benefits of floriculture

Flower farming is not one but many environmental and economic benefits of flower farming.  Flowers are not only beautiful to look at, but they are beneficial for our environment and for us in many ways as well, some of these major benefits are mentioned below.

As we all are aware that generally bees, butterflies, herons etc. are insect moths who drink the juice of flowers.  This is to say that the pollen of flowers is used by these wonderful insect moths as their food.  And when they take pollen from a male flower and sit on a female flower, they deposit that pollen in their pistol where the female reproductive organs, called ovules, live.  This process of pollination is very important for agriculture and food production, because of this process only fruits and seeds are produced.  Without this process agriculture and food production is difficult.  Therefore, the biggest advantage of Flower Farming is that it helps in the process of pollination.

Floriculture can be started at an early stage with very low investment and the entrepreneur or farmer can use the same farming tools to start it.  There is also no need to buy new agricultural equipment, which he already has.

Cultivation of flowers is also very beneficial from the environmental point of view as any flower has to go through the process of photosynthesis to produce chlorophyll.  And during this process, these flowering plants absorb carbon dioxide from the air and release oxygen.  Due to which man gets clean oxygenated air.

Since the entrepreneur has to do some physical work in cultivating flowers, due to which he gets exercise and health is good.

How to start flower cultivation?  

Though starting a flower farming business is not a difficult task in India, but running it successfully for a long time is really no less than a challenge.  Therefore, anyone who is thinking of starting this business must first seriously consider whether he is capable of running it for a long time.  Although agricultural laborers are easily found in rural areas, success cannot be expected in this work only by relying on the laborers, sometimes the entrepreneur may have to work hard.  Therefore, the entrepreneur also needs to be prepared for this.  Apart from this, if it is possible, in which markets it will sell the product it produces, it is very good if you assess and inspect it in advance.

1. Land and water for flower farming

Flower Farming The most important thing for cultivating flowers is the land because the cultivation of flowers will be started on the ground itself.  Even if the entrepreneur builds the poly house etc., he still needs the land.  And keep in mind that this type of farming can be started easily from the rural areas of Flower Farming as most people from rural India want to start a business related to agriculture.  So if the interested person has land in rural area then he can start this business easily, even if he is not, he can start this business by taking land on lease or rent.  Because usually in rural areas, land and agricultural laborers become cheaper and easily available.  But along with the land, the entrepreneur must also consider the management of water as there are many flowers which cannot be produced without water.

2. Selection of flowers based on climate for cultivation

The entrepreneur who wants to start flower farming should contact the agriculture department of the state and discuss with the agricultural scientists about which flower farming in their area would be suitable based on the climate.  Although the climate of India is tropical, cultivation of tropical flowers is possible here.  But in spite of this, one should decide only after taking the opinion of agricultural scientists that which flowers to cultivate will be commercially beneficial for him.  Keep in mind that the selection of flowers for floriculture should be based on the climate and available resources, otherwise the entrepreneur may fail to make profit from this business.

3. Understand the challenges

As we all know very well that no matter what the business is, there are challenges in it.  Even the person who employs a vegetable cart in the street neighborhoods is worried that if his vegetables are not sold and what will happen if they rot?  But worrying does not work, but the person who has solved it will be able to do that business successfully.  Similarly, there are many challenges in Flower Farming.  For how long can the flowers be kept safe after plucking?  Where to sell produced flowers?  And so on.  Therefore, the entrepreneur needs to understand the challenges faced in this business so that the entrepreneur needs to work with an entrepreneur doing a flower farming business.  So that he can closely assess the challenges faced in this business.  And then decide whether he can do this business or not.  However, the biggest challenge is finding a market for flowers or finding customers.

4. Estimate Cost

However, if the entrepreneur has his own land, then the cost of starting flower farming is reduced to a great extent.  After land, the second most important thing is the agricultural laborers who are able to work as daily wages in the floriculture of the entrepreneur.  Apart from this, there is also a need to buy agricultural implements, tillage, flowers seeds etc.  Therefore, when the entrepreneur is estimating the cost, he should closely assess all the types of costs.  So that he can keep himself mentally and financially prepared accordingly.  As far as agricultural laborers are concerned, in the initial phase the farmer can use his family members and when the business starts growing, then he can keep the laborers by paying wages.

5. Work Hard Produce

Now, because the entrepreneur has started the flower farming business and has come to know what kind of flowers he has to cultivate and where to produce and sell them.  Therefore, the only aim of the entrepreneur should be to increase production, for this, the entrepreneur can use modern equipment, fertilizers and other medicine.  Since it is a work related to farming, the entrepreneur should be prepared to do both physical work, and get it done.

entry.title: Cultivation of marigold flower is low cost and good profit in short time
entry.content:
Marigold is a very useful and easily grown flower plant.It is mainly a decorative crop.It is grown for open flowers, garlands and landscapes.Its flowers are opened in the market and garlands are made and sold.Due to the different height of the marigold and the shade of different colors, it has great importance in enhancing the beauty of the landscape.It also plays an important role in decorating the pavilion in marriage.It is a very suitable plant for beds and herbaceous borders.The ornate value of this plant is highly high as it can be cultivated throughout the year.And its flowers have great importance in religious and social festivals.African marigold and French marigold are mainly cultivated in our country.Marigold is a very useful and easily grown flower plant.It is mainly a decorative crop.It is grown for open flowers, garlands and landscapes.It is also a good source of yellow pigment in chickens.Its flowers are opened and sold in the market by making garlands.Due to the different height of the marigold and the shade of different colors, it has great importance in enhancing the beauty of the landscape.It also plays an important role in decorating the pavilion in marriage.It is a very suitable plant for beds and herbaceous borders.The ornate value of this plant is highly high as it can be cultivated throughout the year.And its flowers have great importance in religious and social festivals.


Marigold is a yellow colored flower.  Actually marigold is a bunch of flowers rather than a flower, almost every leaf of it is a flower.The scientific name of marigold is Tagetes species.It is widely grown in different parts of India, especially in the plains.Mexico and South America are flowers of origin.  The reason for lilies being popular in our country is that it can be grown easily in different geographical climates.Three marigold crops are grown in the plains, making its flowers available almost throughout the year.  In the northern Indian state of Himachal Pradesh, small farmers also grow marigold crops for decoration and garlands.

These are advanced varieties of marigold

1. African Marigold - Pusa Orange Marigold, Pusa Basanti Marigold, Alaska, Apricot, Burpese Miracle, Burpese Hunite, Cracker Jack, Crawn of Gold, Coopied, Dublin, Flussy Ruffles, Fire Glow, Geant Sunset, Golden Age, Golden Climax Giant,  Golden Jubilee, Golden Memoiam, Golden Yellow, Goldsmith, Happiness, Hawaii, Honey Comb, Mr. Moonlight, Orange Jubilee, Primrose, Soberan, Riverside, Sun Giants,Super Chief, Double, Texas, Yellow Climax, Yellow Fluffy, Yellowstone, Giant Double African Orange, Giant Double African Yellow etc.

Hybrids- Apollo, Climax, First Lady, Gold Lady, Gray Lady, Moon Sot, Orange Lady, Shobot, Toriodor, Inca Yellow, Inca Gold, Inca Oragan etc.

2. French marigold

(A) Single: Dianti Marietta, Naughty Marietta, Sunny, Tetra Ruffled Red etc.

(B) Double: Bolero, Bonita, Brauni Scott, Barsip Gold Nugget, Barsip Red and Gold, Butter Scotch, Carmen, Couped Yellow, Eldorado, Fosta, Goldie, Gypsy Dwarf Double, Harmony, Lemon Drop, Melody, Midgate Harmony, Orange  Flame, Petite Gold, Petite Harmony, Primrose Climax, Red Brocade, Rusty Red, Spanish Brocade, Spungold, Spree, Tangerine, Yellow Pigmy etc.

Land selection and preparation

Marigold can be cultivated in different types of land.But for proper vegetative growth and proper growth of flowers, proper sunny place is considered best.  For the cultivation of marigold, sandy loam soil with proper drainage having a pH between 5.6 to 6.5 is good.  Alkaline and acidic land is considered to be a hindrance for its commercial cultivation, so one should not forget to cultivate marigold in such land.Before plowing the plants, the soil should be plumped by plowing the field properly.

Climate and land

In northern India, Sharad is grown in the plains and in the mountainous regions of North India it is cultivated in the summer.Cultivation of marigold Baluy loam is considered to be a good land with proper drainage.  The land of which P.H.  The value is between 7.0 and 7.5, the land is considered good for farming.

Field preparation

Marigold seed is first sown in the nursery.Adequate dung manure is prepared in the nursery by plowing well.  Sand is also made by making the soil brittle and make beds in the prepared field or nursery.  The beds should be made 15 cm high by one meter wide and 5 to 6 meters long.  Sow the seeds in these finished beds, filter the rotten cow dung and cover the seeds in the top.And till the seeds begin to freeze, then irrigate with Hazare, in this way we prepare the plants in the nursery.

Seed sowing

The quantity of marigold seeds is based on the varieties.For example, seeds of hybrid varieties 700 to 800 grams per hectare and seeds of common varieties 1.25 kg per hectare are sufficient.In India, its sowing is done at different times according to the variation of climate.In North India, seeds are sown at two times, such as sowing from March to June and sowing from August to September.

Plantation

Marigold plants are planted in flat beds, the distance of planting depends on the varieties grown.In the transplanting of African marigold plants, the distance of 60 cm from line to line and 45 cm from plant to plant keep distance, and in other varieties transplanting is 40 cm from plant to plant and line to line distance.

Irrigation

Marigold is a herbaceous plant.  Therefore, its vegetative growth is very fast.Generally, it completes its vegetative growth in 55-60 days and enters the reproductive stage.Irrigate at intervals of 10-15 days in winter and 5-7 days in summer.

Manure and fertilizer

250 to 300 quintals of rotten cow dung should be mixed at the rate of per hectare while preparing the field, for this, 120 kg of nitrogen, 80 kg of phosphorus and 80 kg of potash should be given per hectare for good crop.  Whole quantity of phosphorus and potash and half the amount of nitrogen should be mixed well while preparing the field.Half the amount of natrijan should be given in equal quantity in two times.The first time should be given after one month of transplanting and second time after two months of transplanting.

Weeding hoeing

The marigold field should be kept clean with weeds and while weeding - weeding should apply 10 to 12 cm high soil on the marigold plants so that the plant does not fall when it flowers.

Disease and Control

Marigold mainly consists of damping off (collar rot), fusarium wilt (ukulele) and viral diseases etc.For the control of humidity and collar rot, treat 2.5 gm of metalexyl (apron) or ketan at the rate of seed per kg of seed.Seeds should be treated with thyram or ketan (2 to 2.5 grams per kg of seeds) to prevent pickling.  For control of viral diseases, uproot and destroy the diseased plants and spray imidacloprid, acetamiprid or thiocloprid if needed.

Pest diseases and control

Kalika clairvoyant, leaf blossom, thrips, red bhurli and red spider mite etc. cause significant damage to marigold.  Sprinkle indoxacarb, chlorantraniliprol or flubendamide to control budding and reddish, while spraying spiromecifene or phenpyroximate for red spider mites.

Harvesting and harvesting

When the marigold crop is ready in our field, the flowers should always be cut early in the morning and the flowers should not be cut diagonally with a sharp knife.After cutting the flowers, it should be spread in a shady place.  Only flowers in full bloom should be harvested.Cut flowers should be kept at a temperature of 8 degrees centigrade and 80 percent humidity to keep them fresh.You can keep one teaspoon of sugar in the flower pot used as a cut flower for more time than mixing it.

Yield

Marigold yield depends on the fertility of the land and the care of the crop, with all the techniques adopted, usually 125 to 150 quintals per hectare is obtained as a flower.Some of the improved varieties produce flowers up to 350 quintals per hectare.This yield is obtained till the end of the entire crop.

2. The easiest way to earn millions of rupees every month is by cultivating rose

Rose cultivation has been practiced all over the world. It is cultivated commercially all over India. Rose flowers are commercially available in the market including cast or cut flowers and petal flowers.Rose cultivation in the country and  Both are very important for export abroad. Rose is grown for cut flowers, rose water, rose oil, gulkand etc. Rose cultivation is mainly done in Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra, Bihar, West Bengal, Gujarat, Haryana, Punjab.  , More is done in Jammu and Kashmir, Madhya Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh. Farmers can earn good profit by cultivating rose.There is no problem of selling them due to increasing demand for flowers and large flower market in the National Capital Region of Delhi.For example, if the king of fruits is mango, then the rose of flowers is rose.The color and aroma of roses fascinate everyone's mind.  Gulkand, rose water, oil, perfume, jam, jelly beverages are made from rose flowers.Flower sticks and bouquets are preferred.Good yield of roses can be achieved with the latest technology.


Rose's business is beneficial

A lot of profit can be made by cultivating rose at a commercial level.  Rose cultivation has been done all over the world. It is cultivated commercially all over India. Rose flowers are found commercially in the market including cast or cut flower and petal flower. Rose cultivation in the country  Both are very important for export abroad. Roses are grown for cut flowers, rose water, rose oil, gulkand etc. Rose cultivation is mainly done in Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra, Bihar, West Bengal, Gujarat, Haryana, Punjab.  , More are done in Jammu and Kashmir, Madhya Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh.

Roses of rose are sold a lot in flower pots.Gulkand is made from rose petals and sugar.The cottage industries of rose water and rose perfume are run.  In Uttar Pradesh, Kannauj, Jaunpur, etc., runs an industry of rose produce.In South India, there are also rose product industries.There is a lot of trade of rose flowers in South India.  Rose flowers are heavily consumed in temples, pavilions, ceremonies, places of worship, etc.  It is a means of economic gain.There, thousands of rural youth make flowers their medium of income.

Rose is a thriving species

About 6 species of roses are found. The first hybrid species that includes Crimson Glory, Mr. Lincoln, Lavazan, Afkennadi, Jawahar, President, Radhakrishnan, First Love, Pooja, Sonia, Ganga, Tata Santanari, Orchid, Super Star, American Heritage  Etc. There are other types of polyantha which include Anjani, Rashmi, dancer, Preet and Swati etc.I third type of Phaloribanda like Banjaran, Dehli Princess, Dimple, Moon, Evergreen, Sonora, Neelambari, Karishma Suryakikaran etc.The fifth type of Miniature Beauty Cricket, Red Flus, Puskala, Babygold Star, Silver Tips etc. and finally the sixth type of Lata Rose are found in it, Black Boy, Land Mark, Pink Meredon, MaryKneel etc.

Suitable climate and land requirement for rose cultivation

Rose cultivation is done in the winter and winter months in the plains and hilly areas of North and South India. Day temperature is considered to be 25 to 30 degree centigrade and night temperature is 12 to 14 degree centigrade. Loam soil and more organic for rose cultivation.  Should be of substance.Values from 5.3 to 6.5 are considered appropriate.

Knowledge of these things is necessary to cultivate rose

By formal layout in terms of beauty, the farm is divided into curios.The length of the bed is 5 meters long and 2 meters wide. The area should be half a meter between two beds.Kyrgyo should be one meter deep in April May to a depth of one meter.The dug should be left open for 15 to 20 days. The curio should be closed from the soil dug by putting dry leaves up to 30 cm in the curry, and the dung manure should be put in the bed a month before then after that fill the bed with water.  Should be given as well as Falidal Powder or Carbofuran 3G to prevent termites.Use it. After about 10 to 15 days after coming to the lips, the distance of the line from the plant and line is made 30 times 60 centimeters in the queue in these lines. It is easy to cut the long flowering flowers by planting the plant at this distance.

How to plant a rose for rose cultivation

Rose is usually planted as soon as the monsoon arrives in July-August.  It is grown extensively in September-October.  If the entire method and process of planting roses is adopted, this flower not only mesmerizes us with its beauty, fragrance and colors till March but also gives benefits.Its bud is prepared by tee budding on top of wild rose.Wild rose pen is planted in the beds in June-July at a distance of about 15 cm. From November to December, twigs come out in these pens, with thorns separated from them.In January, take a twig from good quality roses, take out a T-shaped bud and tie it up in a tee over wild roses and tie it tightly with polythene. Jig-Jyo increases the temperature only then the twigs come out in July. Planting for transplanting in July August.It is prepared. Planting of seedlings in North India should be done by carefully digging the seedlings from September to October. While planting, take care that the grass should be removed from the pindi and planted at a height of 15 cm from the ground surface. After planting.  Should be irrigated immediately.

Fertilizer and fertilizers needed in rose farming

To get the best quality flowers, after pruning, one should apply 10 kg of dung rotten manure per soil mixed with soil. After one week of fertilization, 200 grams of neem cake is 100 grams of bone powder and chemical when new copal starts bursting.  A mixture of manure should be given 50 grams per plant. The ratio of the mixture should be one ratio two ratio one means urea, super phosphate, potash.

Water management for irrigation

Irrigation for rose should be good management.Irrigation should be done after 5 to 7 days in summer and 10 to 12 days in winter as required.

This is how to cut flowers

In the open petals of white, red and pink flowers, the flowers should be cut when the top petals start turning downwards.While cutting the flowers one or two leaves should be left on the twig, so that the plants can grow.  There should not be any problem. While harvesting flowers, water should be kept in a vessel along with water so that the flowers can be cut and kept immediately.The water in the vessel must be at least 10 cm deep, so that the stem can also be preservative in the water submerged in the water.  Mixing. Flowers should be removed for grading after placing them in water for at least 3 hours.If grading is to be done late, then flowers should be kept cold storage at 1 to 3 degree centigrade temperature so that the quality of flowers is good.

Rose plants can be easily grown in earthen pots, which are at least 30 cm deep and equally deep.  For miniature roses, 20 to 25 cm size pots are sufficient.Pots should be kept in a clean environment.As soon as new seedlings and branches start sprouting, keep them in sunlight.They must get 4-5 hours of sunlight throughout the day.  Yes, 1-2 hours in hot summer sun is enough.

Whenever the rose blooms everywhere, its beauty spreads everywhere.In February-March, the rose is at its full puberty and spring.  Come, grow it in your home garden and enjoy its beauty and aroma.The yield of the rose depends on the fertility of the soil and the species of the crop. However, usually around 200 to 250 quintals per hectare is obtained.This yield comes from cut flowers throughout the year.
