entry.title: Fenugreek is good for spicy and green vegetables, you can also take advantage of this by farming
entry.content:
Fenugreek is the main vegetable crop of northern India.The leaves are used in the initial stage of this crop.It is grown almost everywhere in India.The fenugreek crop can also be grown easily in the hilly areas which are grown in the autumn season.The botanical name of the common fenugreek is Trigonella foenmgresium and another class of musk fenugreek whose botanical name is Trigonella carniculata.Fenugreek is cultivated mainly for vegetables, Dano (spices) and in some places for all four.  Dried seeds of fenugreek are used as spices, in vegetables for seasoning and cooking, pickles and medicines.Its bhaji is highly effective, which is compared to the cod liver oil.Due to the steroid called diosgening in its seeds, there is a demand for it in the pharmaceutical industry.It is used in making various Ayurvedic medicines.  Advanced fenugreek production technology is being described in this article.


Climate and land suitable for fenugreek cultivation

Fenugreek is an autumn crop and is cultivated during the Rabi season.The long cold climate, humid climate and low temperature are suitable for its vegetative growth.When the flowers are formed or the grains are formed, there is increased humidity and outbreak of insects due to excess moisture in the air and cloud cover.The cold and dry season is beneficial for yield at the time of harvesting.Fenugreek is more tolerant than other crops.The field should be clean and brittle, otherwise germination is affected.Chlorpyrifas should be applied at the rate of 20 kg per hectare at the time of final cultivation of the field, to protect it from underground insects and termites.Pata must be run after plowing so that moisture is preserved.

Improved species of mentha

Improved species of fenugreek such as Pusa Early Bunching, Kasuri Menthi, Lem Selexan 1, Rajendra Kranti, Pant Ragani, MH-103, CO-1, R. Am T-1 and R. Am T-143, Gujarat Fenugreek-  2, RMT-1, Hisar Sonali, Coimbatore-1 etc. are the major cultivar varieties.

Preparation of field for cultivation of fenugreek

After the first plowing in the preparation of the field with a soil-plowing plow, two-three plowings should be done with the native plow or cultivator, by planting the field and making it flat and rough.Rotten cow dung manure should be mixed. October to November is the best time for sowing fenugreek crop, but in April, March is the right time for fenugreek season.If we sow late then fenugreek yield is less.For more production, it is 12 cm in length.According to the distance from plant to plant.The depth of seed should not be more than 6 cm.

Manure and fertilizer

Dung or compost manure (10-15 tons / ha) at the time of preparation of field.  It is a pulses crop, hence its root is nitrogenous state, hence it is necessary to give less nitrogen to the crop.After cultivation of fenugreek, mix neem leaf, tobacco datura and sow after 15 to 18 days, 20-25 kg as chemical fertilizer.Nitrogen, 40-50 kg.  Phosphorus and 20-30 kg.Potash / O  Seeds should be given in rows at the time of sowing.If the farmer wants to give this quantity of fertilizers through urea, single super phosphate and muriate of potash, then 1 bag of urea, 5 bags of single super phosphate and 1 bag of murate of potash per hectare is sufficient.

Weeding in fenugreek crops

The first weeding is done 25 to 30 days after sowing and the second 30 days after the first, if weeds grow more, then within 30 days after sowing, dissolve 30 percent pendimethalin 3.3 liters in 1000 liters of water.Spraying should be done as per hectare, so that there is no accumulation of weeds.

Disease and Pest Control

For the prevention of root rot disease, seed treatment and soil treatment should be done with organic fungicide Trichoderma.The crop cycle should be adopted.Carbendazim should be sprayed with 0.1% and 0.2% quantity of soluble sulfur for Bhubhia or Churnil Asita disease.Spraying 0.2% dimethoate (Rogar) or imidacloprid 0.1% solution in case of an outbreak of moth and using chlorpyrifas at the rate of 4 liters per hectare with irrigation water should be observed in the field.

Cutting and Sowing

The harvesting of fenugreek depends on its variety and the part used.  The first harvesting of fenugreek leaves for vegetables starts about 4 weeks after sowing.The plant is cut from near the ground surface.Usually 4-5 harvesting is done at regular intervals.  Harvesting for Dano When the crop starts yellowing and most of the leaves fall off the upper leaves and the color of the fruits turns yellow, harvesting of the crop should be done because Dano starts to fall from the fruits due to not harvesting in the right condition.After harvest, the plants are tied in bundles and dried in shade for 1 week. After drying, the bundles are beaten with wood with the help of wood by placing them on a paved floor or tarpaulin, so that the grain comes out of the pods.  Thresher can also be used for this purpose.After cleaning the seeds, should be filled in sacks and stored in ventilated air-conditioned beds.

Fenugreek seed production and green vegetables

When the crop is sown to get an empty leaf, the yield is 90 to 100 quintals per hectare. If the crop grows for both leaf and seed, 15 to 20 quintals from 2 to 3 leaf cuttings and 8- 10 later.Quintal seed is obtained, when the crop is grown only to obtain seed, 12 to 15 quintal seeds are produced.

2. Cultivation of turkey is not less than a profitable deal

Turmeric is a plant of the geninivancy family.Its botanical name is Kurkama Langa.It originated in Southeast Asia.  Turmeric has been used in various forms since ancient times, because it has color-smelling and medicinal properties.Turmeric has both bio preservation and bio destruction properties, as it protects the fibers and kills bacteria (bacteria).  Along with its use in medicinal form, it has been used in all auspicious days in the society since ancient times.At present, the best cosmetic products are made from turmeric itself.Kurkamin is found in turmeric and allirosin is also extracted from it.Turmeric has the highest amount of starch.Apart from this, 13.1 percent water, 6.3 percent protein, 5.1 percent fat, 69.4 percent carbohydrate, 2.6 percent fiber and 3.5 percent mineral salts are found in nutrients.  Vanatin orange red oil is found in 1.3 to 5.5 percent.India is the largest producer of turmeric in the world.  Turmeric in India is exported in various forms to Japan, France USA, United Kingdom, Germany, Netherlands, Saudi Arabia and Australia.


Choice of land

Turmeric is cultivated successfully in the Baluy loam or Mattiar loam soil.  There should be proper drainage system.If the land is slightly acidic, then turmeric can be cultivated successfully.

Land preparation

There is a need to prepare the land properly for the cultivation of turmeric, because it is inside the ground, so it is necessary to make the land well brittle.  After plowing at least one foot deep from the molded bold plow, the land should be prepared well by running the cultivator two or three times and by rolling it in it, the ground should be leveled and the larger ones should be shortened.

Manure and fertilizer

Good rotten cow dung manure should be used in the range of 20 to 25 tons hectare, because by applying cow dung manure, the land will become well brittle and any chemical fertilizer given will be used properly.After this, potash should be used at the value of 100120 kg of nitrogen 6080 kg of Sphur and 80100 kg of hectare.Potash is very important for the cultivation of turmeric, which farmers do not use, both the quality and yield of turmeric is affected.Only one fourth of nitrogen and full quantity of sphur and potash should be given at the time of sowing and the remaining quantity of nitrogen should be divided into two parts and the first should be given 40 to 60 days after sowing and second only after 80 to 100 days.

Crop circle

For successful cultivation of turmeric, it is necessary to adopt the proper crop cycle.It should be kept in mind that turmeric should not be cultivated continuously on the same land, because this crop draws more and more nutrients from the ground so that if you do not cultivate it in the same land for the second year, it would be better.In irrigated areas, turmeric can be cultivated successfully by adopting crop rotation with crops like maize, potato, chilli, jowar, paddy, groundnut.

Varieties developed

Spice variety, Poona, Sonia, Gautam, Rashim, Suroma, Roma, Krishna, Guntur, Megha, Halda 1, Sukarna, Sugandhan and C.O.1 are the major castes that farmers can choose.  If only a little is found, then your seed can be prepared.

Sowing

Farmer brothers who have adequate water facility can apply turmeric from second fortnight of April to first week of July.But those who lack sufficient amount of irrigation facility, they can apply turmeric as soon as the monsoon rains begin, but the cultivation should be done well in advance.After preparing the ground well, make five-seven-meter, long and two-three meter wide beds, cut from 30 to 45 cm in a row and keep a distance of 20 to 25 centimeters from the saplings at a depth of four to five centimeters.The tubers should be planted.  Applying turmeric in this way is 12 - 15 quintals.  Bales are required.

Irrigation

Turmeric does not require much irrigation, but if the crop is sown in summer, four to five irrigations are required till the rain starts.After the monsoon, irrigation is not required.But if there is no rain in the middle or if it becomes dry and if it does not rain after October, then it is necessary to irrigate at an interval of 20-25 days in such a situation.In the month of November, the growth of leaves and the thickness of Dhankanda starts increasing, then at that time it is necessary to plow the soil to get more yield, which increases the growth of the tubers and increases the production.

Drainage

Proper management of drainage should be done otherwise turmeric crop has adverse effect and plants and leaves start yellowing, so proper arrangement should be made to drain excess rainwater from time to time.

weed control

It is necessary to do two or three weeding to have a good turmeric crop.  The first weeding should be done 80-90 days after sowing and the second weeding should be done after one month but if weeds come already and it seems that the crop is getting affected then a weeding can be done before that.Along with this, we should also do the hoeing from time to time, so that air circulation can be good and complete development of turmeric crop which is directly related to production.

Pest control

Generally, not much problem of insects has been observed in turmeric. Sometimes, there is a problem of insect bites and juice suckers.For the stem weed, one of the two medicines can be used according to 10 kg hectare.

Harvesting

The crop sown in May-June becomes worth digging by the month of February, at this time, the money buds develop and the leaves begin to turn yellow and dry only then it should be understood that turmeric is ripe and can now be harvested or dug.  First the plants should be cut from the crocodile and after plowing with the plow turmeric tubers can be removed easily, wherever the need is considered, spade can also be used.The early crop of turmeric is ready by ripening in seven-eight-eight months and in 9-10 months of late ripening.

Yield

Where fertilizer and cow dung manure have been used in the above mentioned area and the crop has been sown in the irrigated area, then 50-100 quintal per hectare and 50-100 quintal per hectare of raw turmeric can be obtained from unirrigated areas.Keep in mind that after drying the raw turmeric remains only 15-25 percent.

the treatment

Turmeric should be used with utmost care while digging so that there is less loss of money and the entire bales can be removed.At the time of boiling, only a few dung or turmeric leaves are boiled with water.By doing this, the color becomes slightly darker and the quality of turmeric increases, which gives a good price in the market.After about three to four hours of cooking, the knots are easily suppressed by pressing between the fingers, then the kadhas are removed and kept in the sun to dry, so that the knots dry well.  After this, the knots are cleaned by rubbing them with a rough thing, this work is done on a large scale on machines and in this way turmeric knots are prepared.

entry.title: In spicy crops, fennel can be cultivated in a very easy way
entry.content:
Fennel is mainly cultivated as a spice. Oil is also extracted from fennel seeds, it is cultivated mainly in Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Punjab and Haryana.  The botanical name is Foeniculum vulgare.  It is commercially cultivated as an annual herb, a thick and aromatic spice crop.  Fennel is known by different names in different parts of the country.


Land and climate suitable for fennel cultivation

Cold and dry climate is best for fennel cultivation. Dry and cold seed set increases the quality of the products as well as the weather during the yield. Its cultivation is well done in autumn, it requires dry climate while cropping. When the seeds are not required, it does not require more coolness. I can be left in every land except for the land of fennel, but the proper management of water exhaust Shallow sandy clay is not conducive to fennel farming. The best soil for fennel cultivation is the sandal soil with black cotton soil and lime. Proper drainage is also an important requisite for professional cultivation of fennel crop.

Fennel's Advanced Species

Many species of fennel are found, such as CO .1, Gujarat Fane 1, R.F 35, R.F 101, R.F 125, N. P.D. 32 and NPD .186, N.P.T.163, NPK.1, NPJ .26, NPJ .269 and NPJ 131, P.F 35, Udaipur Fore S.1 and G.F.1 etc.

RF 101- Long, straight and thick tan; Long, and bold grains; Mature in 150-160 days; The average yield is 15.5 quintals / hectare. Small plants with RF 125 compact umbels; Long, bold grains; Mature in 110-130 days; The yield is 17.3 quintals / hectare

RF 35- long, medium size, plats spread with bald and green seeds; Sweet disease, leaf and leaf-tushar tushed; Mature in 225 days; Average yield of 12.8 quintal / hectare.

Gujarat Fennel 1- Long and wild plants with rectangular-medium bold and dark green seeds; Toler to spot sweet disease and leaf; Mature in 225 days; Average yield / hectare is 16.5 cue; Suitable for quick-sowing; Dry tolerant

Co-1- long plants with medium diffused branches; With the average yield of 5.67q / hectare mature in 220 days; Suitable for dry affected, water filler, saline and alkaline condition; Suitable for mountainous areas.

Preparation of farm for fennel farming

Fennel seeds can be sown directly in the main area or picked in the nursery beds and later can be implanted in the main area. The first plowing soil is made by the solving solution and after 3 to 4 plowing domestic solution or the cultivator, it is made to make a plate and made a bit of it.

Sowing of fennel

On sowing directly by the seed, it seems approximately 12 to 15 kg per hectare seed. Only 4 to 5 kilograms per hectare seed on the plantation. Ideal sowing time for fennel is between September until October. Delayed delay in sowing reduces. Seed rate for sowing is ha / 10-12 kg. In addition to sowing, the rows should be deeply in the rows with the difference of 45-60cm. After the sowing area is irrigated.

Quantity of manure and fertilizers in fennel cultivation

150 to 200 quintals of rotten cow dung as well as 80 kilograms of nitrogen, 60 kg of phosphorus and 40 kg of potash should be given per hectare. Half the amount of phosphorus and potash of nitrogen is collected at the time of final preparation at the time of field preparation.  I and half of the remaining nitrogen should be given after 60 days of sowing 1/2 and the remaining 1/2 part after 90 days in the standing crop.

Water management work in fennel cultivation

First irrigation is done soon after seed sowing and after that one or two light irrigations are required till seed germination. Later, the crop is irrigated at intervals of 15-25 days.  Water stress may adversely affect seed formation and grain yield during this phase as water stress should be avoided during flowering and seed formation.

Weeding of fennel crop

It is necessary to do weeding after first irrigation and second weeding after 45 to 50 days. There is a fear of breaking the plant during weeding after big crop. A serious problem in commercial cultivation of weed fennel crop.  is.  First hoeing and weeding is recommended 30 days after sowing.  Both mechanical and chemical control of weeds can be practiced.  Herbicides are used for weed control, Pendimethalin is the most effective.  Pre-emergence application of pendimethalin @ 1.0kg / ha effectively supplemented with a manual weeding 50 days after sowing control weeds.

How to cure disease in fennel cultivation

Most mahoo and leaf-eating insects in fennel are sprayed with 0.2 percent carbaryl solution.

How to harvest fennel crop

Fennel matures in 170180 days.  The fennel should be harvested only when the fennel amble is fully grown and the seeds are fully ripened and dried. They should be harvested and dried in sunlight for one to two days and dried in shade for 8 to 10 days to keep the green color. Green fennel  In order to get it, when bunch of Ambal flowers should be harvested 30 to 40 days. After harvesting, it should be dried thoroughly under shade.When whole seeds are harvested, yield 10 to 15 quintals per hectare and when some green seeds are harvested and harvested, the yield is reduced to 9 to 10 quintals per hectare.

2.Learn how to cultivate coriander in a spicy crop

Coriander is a aromatic green leaf used in Indian kitchens to make food even more delicious.  It is commonly used as vegetable decoration, medicine and fresh spices. Since ancient times the country of India is known as "Land of Spices" in the world.  Coriander seeds and leaves are useful in making food aromatic and delicious.  Coriander seeds have a lot of medicinal properties and are used as culinary, carminative and diuretic.  Coriander is a one-year spice crop of Ambeli Ferry or Carrot clan.  Its green coriander is called cilantro or Chinese Pursley.  Coriander is also an economically beneficial crop with valuable multi-use spices.  Coriander seeds and leaves are useful in making food aromatic and delicious.  Coriander seeds have a lot of medicinal properties and are used as culinary, carminative and diuretic.  India is a major exporter of coriander.  Foreign exchange is earned by exporting coriander.


Climate and land for coriander cultivation

Coriander is cultivated almost every year for the use of green leaves, but it is cultivated along with the Rabi crop for getting seeds. For this, the spring season is good. Loam soil is best for coriander cultivation in good soil rich lands.  Can also be cultivated, but drainage is very important. A land which has high amount of organic matter and proper drainage system is also suitable for its cultivation.  PH of land for its cultivation  The value should be between 6.5-8, as more acidic and saline soil is not suitable for its cultivation.

Coriander

Species in coriander such as Pusa Selection 360, RC.1, UD.20, UD21, Pant Haritama, Sadhana, Swati, DH.5, CG.1, CG.2  , Indus, CO.1, CO.2 and CO.3, CS 287, R.K.  D.44 and Azad Dhaniya 1 and R.C.R. 20, 41, 435, 436 and 446 etc.

So prepare for cultivation of coriander

For the preparation of the field, the first plowing of the field is done with soil plow and later three to four plowing cultivators or native plows, the field should be leveled to make it coarse.  Should be mixed.

Quantity of seed in coriander sowing

It is sown at the rate of 25-30 kg of seeds per hectare.  Before sowing the seeds should be lightly rubbed or broken and divided into two parts.  Antibiotic drugs like Bavistin 2 grams per kg before sowing coriander seeds.  It is necessary to be treated at the rate of seed.  By soaking the seeds treated in this way for 24 hours, sowing was found to be up to 71.33 percent germination.  Coriander seeds germinate about 10 days after sowing.  Coriander is grown year round, to be used as a leaf.  Whereas for the purpose of seed, a crop is taken in northern and central India, which is sown in October.  While two crops are grown in southern India.  In the hilly areas, it is sown in March.  Sowing is done in Karnataka and Tamil Nadu in the month of May.

Fertilizer and fertilizer in coriander crop

While preparing the field, rotten manure of 100 to 120 quintal dung should be added to the final plowing. Also, 60 kg of nitrogen, 40 kg of phosphorus and 40 kg of potash should be given per hectare. Half the amount of nitrogen and full amount of phosphorus and potash.  The quantity should be given in basal dressing at the last plowing while preparing the field. 1/2 part of the remaining amount of nitrogen should be given after 25 days of sowing and 1/2 part after 40 days of sowing.

Arrangement of irrigation in coriander crop

Coriander leaves need to be irrigated at equal and lesser intervals to keep them green and soft and lush.  The total number of irrigation depends on the type of land and the season.  Irrigate about 3-4 times in heavy soil and 5-6 times in light soil.

Coriander crop harvesting and harvesting

Green leaves should be carefully harvested so that the stem should be plucked twice as it is safe, but sometimes the entire plant also uses green leaves to get seeds and harvested when the seeds are ripened and dried on the plant.  The seeds are harvested after drying and put in the field for a couple of days. The yield of green leaves is 125 to 140 quintals per hectare and 10 to 12 quintals of dry coriander seeds are obtained.

entry.title: Prepare manure without cost for advanced crops
entry.content:
Compost is prepared without cost for advanced crops.Compost is a type of compost which is obtained by decomposition and recycling of organic matter.It is the main component of bio agriculture.



The simplest way to make compost is to wait for some time by making a pile of moist organic matter (like leaves, leftover food, etc.) so that it gets dissolved.Dissolution takes a few weeks or months.He then transforms into Humus.The modern method of making compost is completed in several stages,and in each phase water, air and carbon and nitrogen rich materials are poured in a very rough manner.Plants require a lot of soil rich in nutrients.Potash and phosphate are found in good quantity in the soil here, but the essential element for plant growth and development is low nitrogen and nitrogen is available in a balanced form by compost.Not only humans,animals and birds all get their staple food from the botanical world, and it combines with sewage and soil to make the land fertile.If it is prepared properly,then we can provide very balanced nutrient to the plants by preparing compost.It is this cycle of food that maintains balance in the vegetative world.Due to the fall of leaves in Biaban forests and regions, the process of rotting continues continuously and the nutrients are continuously available to the vegetation.In nature, this rotting and melting occurs with the help of bacteria.It has also been observed that this bacterium goes smoothly to a depth of about one meter (3 ft).


So let's prepare a pit for compost accordingly - dig a pit for compost, which should be three feet long and three feet wide.In the pit,first moisten it by spraying water all around and the leaves,plants,kitchen and other melting waste of the house are 30 cm.Fill to the height.Spread a fold of cow dung on it.After this,again spray garbage, garbage,leaves etc.After this,press the entire pit with the foot and put enough water on it.  In this way, fill the pit full with mud and close it well with water from time to time.In this process, compost full of nutrients will be prepared for you in three to four months and household waste and waste will be utilized properly.

which are eaten by some four legs and the substances which remain undigested, come out in the form of cow dung along with other impurities in the body.It is usually moist, semi-solid, but it also changes according to the animal's food.The dung of animals that depend only on green grass or more oil is thin.Its color is somewhat yellow and thick brown.Grass, straw, grain pieces, etc. are present in it and can be easily identified.On drying it turns into a hard mass.

1.For information, let us tell you that there are two methods of composting cow dung first in India -

Cold method- For this purpose, well-sized, 20-25 feet long, 5-6 feet wide and 3 to 10 feet deep, are dug and dung is filled in them.  While filling, press it in such a way that no space is left vacant.  The upper part of the fabric is made like a dome and the cow dung is coated with it, so that the unnecessary water of the rainy season does not enter it.  After that, leave the fertilizer to be made for about three months.  In this method, the temperature of the fabric never goes above 34 degrees, because the chemical activity in the fabric is limited due to lack of air.In this method, nitrogenous materials are not allowed to come out of the compost.

Hot method - In this method, a thin layer of dung is pressed without pressing.Chemical changes occur in the presence of air, causing the temperature to be 60 C.Is reached.  The fold is then pressed and a second thin fold is put on it to allow the temperature to rise.In this way the pile becomes ten to twenty feet high, which is left in this state for a few months.In this way, the special benefit is that the seeds of grass, coarse and other harmful plants, which can be present in cow dung, are destroyed when the temperature increases.Thus 5 to 6 tons of manure can be made from each animal.

Vermicomposting is the benefit of earthworm manure - making earthworm compost (manure) of the bio-decomposable waste material by the earthworm and emitting it is called vermicomposting.By adding vermicompost to the soil, the fertility of the soil not only increases, but also increases the yield and quality of the crops.Excessive use of chemical fertilizers improves the side effects on the soil with the use of vermicompost.  In this way, the vermi compost also contributes significantly to the soil's fertile strength by improving the physical, chemical and biological condition of the soil.

Approximately 1 kg  Weights range from 1000 to 1500 earthworms.  Usually 1 earthworm produces 2 to 3 cocoons per week.Thereafter 1 to 3 earthworms come out of every cocoon in 3-4 weeks.An earthworm has the capacity to produce about 250 earthworms in its life.The newborn earthworm enters reproductive state at about 6-8 weeks.Every day an earthworm consumes approximately equal to its weight, converting it into compost.One kg  Earthworms 25 to 30 kg of 45 kg of degradable material in one square meter area.  

2.That's why organic farming should be used

Improved crop is becoming a very big question for the farmers, for this, they are also using many types of chemical fertilizers, but there are benefits but also a lot of losses.For this, keeping in mind the natural security, the use of organic farming will be simple and prosperous as well as without cost.  And the best thing is that there is no harm to it from the natural point of view.Scientists have given the name to organic farming because they consider the present-day farming as traditional farming, however, if we talk about India, then before India, traditional farming was done only in the organic way, without any kind of chemical crop.But after independence, India started the Green Revolution to become self-sufficient in the matter of crops, with the help of chemicals and pesticides, those crops were also produced in abundance, which could never be imagined.  Due to the Green Revolution, there was a lot of growth in the cultivation of wheat, millet and maize.


Today, per hectare has increased to more than 100 kg, so think about how much chemical is being used in crops.  The organic farming that India had been trying for years due to the Green Revolution was over, and the cultivation of chemicals was considered as traditional farming, in which a lot of chemicals are being used.But the fertility of soil is decreasing due to which many fields have become barren.

Now, seeing the increasing effect of chemical farming in the present day, scientists have proved it fatal, which is affecting not only the soil but also the health of humans.In view of the increasing impact of this, scientists have termed organic farming as good for soil fertility and human health. Today, people suffering from many diseases are instructed to eat crops grown from organic farming, due to which many farmers have given organic  Adoption has been done. Although organic farming is getting very small at the moment, but if awareness is spread, it will take the form of traditional farming in the coming times.

3.So let's know now the ill effects of chemical fertilizers

Due to the high amount of chemical fertilizers, the use of organic manure has decreased, so the amount of fertilizer available in the soil has reduced.This has affected soil texture and air circulation in the soil.The use of chemical fertilizers has reduced the number of microorganisms in the soil and the soil's waterfilling capacity and erosion have also decreased.The running water has washed away the fertile upper soil.Due to the use of crops grown from chemical fertilizers, humans are suffering from many long term diseases.

It is a misconception of these chemical fertilizers that even newborn children are suffering from diseases like diabetes and at the age of 20 years the hair of the youngsters starts turning white.Apart from this, these are also directly related to incurable diseases like cancer.Farmers have to depend on external agencies to buy chemicals, which costs so much, which has made the profits in agriculture only false.  This is the reason why farmers themselves are moving towards happiness and this is the reason that the coming generation is not turning to agriculture and turning to the city.The government declares a loan package rather than a real solution to the problem.The only solution to this complex problem is sustainable farming  

4.Non-chemical farming

Nowadays many non-scientific methods of farming are being used, in which organic farming, natural zero tillage, sustainable farming, bio-dynamic avedic farming, etc.are many new words which raise doubts among the farmers.Organic farming should be such that it improves the well being of plants and other animals.  It should be to enhance and preserve biodiversity.It is prepared using local materials to do organic farming.  If farming becomes profitable then the migration of youth towards cities will be reduced.In this way, organic farming can solve environmental degradation and pollution.

 5.So let's know the benefits of organic farming no 

 The biggest advantage of organic farming is that it can preserve the soil and fertility of your farm for a long time,so that profitable farming can also be done without the use of chemicals.After the use of organic farming, you can also plant crops in your fields that have not been done till date because any kind of crop can be sown after the fertility of soil increases.Organic farming will also have a direct impact on the animals as there will be no amount of chemicals in their food, then the quality of milk given by them will be better and the health of the animals will also be better.This will have long-term consequences on animals as well as humans, which can prevent many incurable diseases and make your health healthy.There will be some problem in the beginning with organic farming, but in the long term, the quality of your crops will be better,so you will get good profits.

entry.title: Farmers can also earn good returns by cultivating Moth as pulses.
entry.content:
Moth is the main crop of Bali pulses crops grown in western Rajasthan. It has greater drought tolerance than other pulses crops.Its roots go deeper and get moisture from the land.The average yield of moth in the western region of the state is 99 percent of the total yield of the state.The average yield of moth is around 338 kg per hectare. 25 to 60 percent higher yield can be obtained on cultivation by advanced techniques.  Apart from being used as a variety of snacks (chaat, papad, bhajiya etc.) are prepared from its lentils.Its dalmoth is a very popular snacks.Moth green beans are used as a vegetable.The nutritional value in moth grains (per 100 grams weight) is 330 kcal of energy, 24 g protein, 1.5 g fat, 61.9 g sugars, 9.6 mg.  Besides iron content and 202 mg calcium, 0.4 mg thiamine, 0.09 mg riboflavin and 1.5 mg niacin are found.


Land preparation

For cultivation of moong, loam and sandy loam land is best.The land should have proper drainage system. First plowing should be done by running a plow turning plow or disc harrow and then by raising a cross plowing harrow and a plowing cultivator.The land should be leveled.

Seed sowing

Mung bean should be harvested by July.In case of delayed rains, early maturing variety may be harvested by 30 July. Healthy and good quality and treated seeds should be used for sowing. Sowing should be done in shears. Distance between shears  45 cm  And the distance from plants to plants is 10 cm.Is appropriate

Crop circle

Appropriate crop cycle should be adopted to obtain crop yield and to maintain fertility of land.In rainfed areas, Moth-Bajra crop cycle is appropriate.

Manure and fertilizer

Being a moth pulses crop, it requires less amount of nitrogen. An area of 20 hectares of nitrogen and 40 kg of phosphorus is required for a hectare area. Integrated nutrient management for moth is appropriate. 2.5 tons of cow dung at the time of field preparation.Or the quantity of compost should be mixed well in the land.After this, 44 kg of DAP and 5 kg of urea should be added to the land at the time of sowing. Before sowing, mix 600 grams of Rhizobium culture in 1 liter of water and 250 grams of good solution.  Should be cured after drying in shade.

weed control

Weeds are very harmful for moth crops. For weed control, a 3.30 liter liter of pendimethalin (Stomp) available in the market should be sprayed uniformly at 500 liters per hectare. When the crop is 25-30 days old  So one piece should be done with Kassi.If the laborer is not available then at the same time 750 milligrams are available in the market.  Lee  Solution should be sprayed in 500 liters of water at the rate of per hectare.

Pest and Disease Control

Termites: Termites cause great damage by cutting the roots of plants.  The plant dries within a few days. To prevent termites, at the time of last plowing, a quantity of 20-25 kg per hectare of qinalphos or chloroparifos powder should be added to the soil and the seeds should be given 2 ml of chloroprifos before sowing.  .  The quantity should be sown by treating seed rate per kg.

Katra: In the early stage of katra braided crop, the plants are harmed by cutting. To control this, the area around the field should be clean and in case of addiction, 20-25 kg of methyl parathion powder should be used per hectare.  I

Jassids: This insect is green in color and damages the crop by sucking the juice from the leaves of the plants. The leaves start to turn twisted. For control of this kit, half a liter of monocrotophos should be mixed with 500 liters of water. Imidacloprid  Of 500 milliliters  The quantity can be sprayed by making a solution in 500 liters of water.

Moyla, Hara Tela and Fly: For the prevention of these pests, Melathion 50 E.C.  1 liter or dimioate 30 EC  Or 25 EC  One liter or Melathion 5% powder should be used at the rate of 25 kg per hectare. For control of Black Leap Beewel and Leap Bitle-in Keto, the amount of 20-25 kg per hectare should be burnt.

Pod Punching: This pest damages the crop by eating the leaves of crop plants.To prevent this, Monocrotophos 36 WAC or Melathion 50 EC or Qinalphon 25 EC.  Half liter or 1.5 kg of powder should be sprayed / sprayed at the rate of 20 - 25 kg ha.

Yellow mosquito virus disease: This disease causes the most damage to the moth crop.  This leaves the affected leaves completely yellow and thick in size.To prevent this, control of the white fly through which the disease spreads is necessary. Immediately after symptoms, dimithoate 30 EC or metacistox half liter and half liter malathion per hectare  The solution should be sprayed in 500 liters of water at the rate of Rs.

Bacterial disease: Plants wilt due to this disease. Due to this disease, small dark brown spots appear on the leaf, legumes and stems.To control this, 200 gm of Agrimycin is dissolved in 500 liters of water per hectare.  Sprinkle should be made. Moth seeds should be 100 ppm.After soaking for one hour in a solution of streptocycline, it should be sown after drying at the rate of 2 grams per kg of seed.

Stem Scorching Disease: Due to this disease, plants start to wilt.If symptoms appear, 2 kg of mancozeb solution should be sprayed in 500 liters of water per hectare.

Kinkle virus disease: Symptoms of this disease appear on the leaves, due to which the leaf becomes thick and heavy, due to this disease the leaves shrink.  Dimithoate 30 EC for its control  Or methyldimetone should be sprayed after mixing in 500 liters of water at the rate of 750 ml per hectare of 25 EC.  Second spraying should be done after 15 days. 

Sarcospora disease: Due to this disease, angular brownish red spots are formed on the leaves.The leaves of the sick plants start to dry yellow and the roots of the plants also become dry. To control this disease, 500 g of Carbendazim 500  The solution should be sprayed at the rate of per hectare by making a solution in liter water. Seeds should be treated at the rate of 3 grams of captan or 2 grams of carbendazim per kilobase before sowing.

Seed production

Farmers can also produce good quality seeds on their fields.Some precautions should be taken while selecting the field.Moths have not been grown in this field last year.There should be a good drainage system in the land.For certified seed, there should not be any field of moth from 10 to 20 meters around the field. Preparation of the field should take special care of seed and its sowing, nutrient management, weed control disease and kit control.Want  From time to time, we should keep the undesirable plants out of the field and while cutting the lata for the seeds, you should harvest the crop by leaving 5 to 10 meters around the field.The moisture should be more than 8-9 percent.After this the seed should be grading.The farmer can use this seed for sowing next year.

Harvesting and mowing

When the beans of the moth are cooked and turned brown and the plant turns yellow, the crop should be harvested. After the lathe is properly dried, the grain is separated by the thresher.

Yield and economic benefits

The yield of 6 to 8 quintals per hectare can be obtained by the advanced techniques of moth. For cultivation of one hectare of moth, it costs Rs. 15 to 18 thousand per hectare. If the market price of moth seeds is Rs. 40 per hectare  If kg, then net profit of Rs 9 to 12 thousand per hectare can be obtained by cultivating moth.

entry.title: Make more profit and deal with gram cultivation
entry.content:
One variety of gram is also called Kabuli chana or Chole in popular language.They are comparatively larger than the dark almond black gram.They have been found in Afghanistan, southern Europe, North Africa, and Chile.They have been introduced to, and are used in the Indian subcontinent since the eighteenth century.Chana is an important pulses crop grown during the Rabi season.India accounts for 70 percent of the world's total gram production.Gram has 21 percent protein, 61.5 percent carbohydrate and 4.5 percent fat.It contains good amount of calcium iron and niacin.  Gram is used to eat in the form of lentils made from its grains and grains.  Its grains are grinded and made into gram flour, from which a variety of dishes and sweets are made.Gram seeds and plants are used as vegetables in the green phase.Gram husk is used as a nutritious food for fodder and grain animals.Gram is also used as a medicine to clean the blood and for other diseases.Gram, being a pulse crop, collects nitrogen from the atmosphere and also increases the fertility of the soil.


Land and its preparation

Light loam or loam soil is good for gram cultivation.There should be proper drainage system in the land.  There should not be much alkalinity in the land.The first plowing should be done with soil reversing plow or disc harrow.After this, a cross should be plowed with harrows and platted to level the land.To protect the crop from infestation of termites and cutworms, 25 kg of powdered haptachlor (4%) or quinalphos (1.5%) or methyl parathion (2%) or endosulfon (1.5%) at the time of last plowing.The quantity should be mixed well in the soil at the rate of per hectare.

Seed treatment

Many kinds of pests and diseases cause damage in gram.To protect the crop from its infestation, seeds should be sown after treatment.While treating the seed, it should be kept in mind that firstly treat it with fungicide, then insecticide and finally with Rajobium culture.For the prevention of root rot and topical disease, treat seeds with a rate of 1.5 to 2 grams of carbendazim or mancozeb or thyram at a rate of 1 kg per kg.To prevent termites and other underground pests, 8 ml of Chlorpyriphos 20 EC or Endosulfan 35 EC should be sown by treating them at the rate of 1 kg per kg of seed.  Finally, the seed should be sown by treating three quantities of Rhizobium culture and three packets of phosphorus soluble bacteria by treating the amount of seed required for one hectare area.  To cure seeds, after heating 250 gm jaggery in one liter of water, it should be treated well by mixing Rhizobium culture and phosphorus soluble bacteria in it.The treated seeds should be sown in shade and sown soon.

Sowing time and sowing

In uncultivated areas, gram should be sown in the first fortnight of October.  Sowing must be done by October 30 in areas where there is irrigation facility.  To get higher yields from the crop, it is necessary to have a reasonable number of plants per unit in the field.  The seed rate required for proper number of plants and the proper distance from row to row and plant to plant have an important role in 80 kg for rainfed farming.And 60 kg for irrigated area.The quantity of seed per hectare is sufficient.For rainfed crop, the depth of the seed is 7 to 10 cm.  And for irrigated area, sowing of seeds is 5 to 7 cm.  Should be done at depth.  The distance from row to row of crop is 45 to 50 cm.But should do.

Manure and fertilizer

Due to pulses of gram crop, it requires less nitrogen because glands are found in the roots of gram plants.The bacteria present in the glands meet the requirement of a significant amount of nitrogen in the plant by stabilizing the nitrogen in the atmosphere.But due to lack of complete growth of the glands in the roots of the plant in the initial stage, the plant has to take nitrogen from the soil.Therefore, for the supply of nitrogen 20 kg.Nitrogen is required per hectare.With this 40 kg  Phosphorus should be given at the rate of per hectare.Nitrogen content can be given by urea or dye ammonium phosphate (DAP) and cow dung and compost manure.While phosphorus can be supplied by single super phosphate or DAP or cow dung and compost manure.Supply of nutrients through integrated nutrient management method is beneficial.For one hectare area, 2.50 tonnes of cow dung or cuspost manure should be mixed well in the soil at the time of land preparation.22 kg at the time of sowing.  Urea and 125 kg  Single Super Phosphate or 44 kg  Mixing 5 kg of urea in DAP and giving it in rows at the rate of one hectare is sufficient.

Irrigation

Most of the gram cultivation is done in the wetlands accumulated in the rainfed areas.If irrigation facilities are available, one or two irrigation can be done in the event of moisture deficiency.First irrigation should be done after 40 to 50 days and second irrigation should be done.In the irrigated areas, 3 to 4 irrigation is sufficient for the cultivation of gram.  Before sowing, sowing the crop should be done.After this, after planting the crop, 35-40 days after sowing should be irrigated first 70-80 days and second and 105-110 days after final irrigation.  If only two irrigation facilities are available after sowing, 40-50 days after the first sowing and second 80-85 days should be done.If only one irrigable water is available after sowing, irrigation should be given priority 60-65 days after sowing.Keep in mind that the field should not be filled with water for a long time, this can cause damage to crop plants.

Weeding and weeding control

Many types of weeds like Bathua, Khartua, Morwa, Pyaji, Motha, Dube etc. grow in gram crop.These weeds affect the yield by competing with crop plants for nutrients, moisture, space and light.Apart from this, many types of diseases and pests also occur in the crop through weeds which also affect the quality of the seeds.Time control is very important to prevent loss by weeds.Twice in a gram crop is sufficient.First hoeing should be done 30-35 days after sowing and second 50-55 days after sowing.If there is no availability of laborers, immediately after sowing the crop, 2.50 liters of Pandymethalein should be dissolved in 500 liters of water and sprayed uniformly in the field by machine.Then a weeding should be done 30-35 days after sowing.In this way, the loss caused by weeds in gram crop can be prevented.

Pest and disease control

There are many types of pests and diseases in the gram crop, which is very important to control at the right time.

Termites, cutworms and wire worms

If the land is treated with endosulfanae cunalphos or chloropyriphos before sowing and the seeds are treated with a chloropyrifos insecticide, then the damage caused by underground insects can be prevented.In case of termite infestation in standing crop, 2 to 3 liters of Chlorpyriphos 20 EC or Endosulfan 35 EC should be given with irrigation at the rate of one hectare.  Keep in mind that it is very important for the insecticide to reach the roots for the control of termites.The caterpillar hides are hidden under the slopes and in the night, cutting the plants near the roots causes damage to the crop.Methyl parathion 2 per cent or qinalphos 1.50 per cent or 25 kg of endosulfone 4 per cent powder should be applied at the rate of one hectare in the evening to control the cutworm.25 kg of trichlorophon 5% powder  The quantity can also be crushed at the rate of per hectare.

Pod borer

This insect damages the crop by eating leaves in the initial stage.When the pod comes in, it makes a hole in it and enters it and after eating the grain makes the pod hollow.To control this pest, 20-25 kg of endosulfon 4 percent or qinalphos 1.5 percent or methyl parathion 2 percent powder before flowering and after flowering in the crop.The quantity should be dry per hectare.On availability of water, 1.25 liters of Monocrotophos 35 EC or Qinulfos 25 EC should be sprayed in 500 liters of water at the rate of one hectare at the time of flowering of the crop.

Blight disease

This disease is caused by a fungus.  Due to this disease, leaving the roots of plants, small round and brown spots are formed on the stem leaves and pods.In the early stages of the plant, its symptoms are clearly visible on the stem near the ground.First the affected plants turn yellow and then brown and finally the plant withers and dies.On appearing symptoms of this disease, one kg of fungicide called mancozeb.  Or one kg of soluble sulfur.Or 1.30 kg of copper oxychloride solution should be sprayed in 500 liters of water.  3-4 sprays at an interval of 10 days is sufficient.

Warts

The symptoms of this disease begin to appear clearly in the sown crop 20-25 days after sowing.Symptoms of the disease in late sown crop appear in February and March.First the affected plants turn yellow and the leaves start drying up from the bottom up, and finally the plant dies after drying.There should be no shortage of moisture in the soil to control this disease.If irrigation facility is available, then irrigation should be done as soon as symptoms of disease are seen.  Sowing of anti-disease varieties like RSG 888 AC 235 and BG 256 should be done.

Kit (Rust)

Symptoms of this disease appear in February and March.On the upper surface of the leaves, light brown to black discolored rashes are formed on the legumes and branches.On appearing symptoms of this disease, one kg of fungicide called mencozeb.  Or one kg of soluble sulfur.Or 1.30 kg of copper oxychloride.  The quantity should be sprayed in 500 liters of water.3-4 sprays at an interval of 10 days is sufficient.

Harvest protection from frost

Due to the effect of frost in the gram crop there is a lot of damage.The probability of frost falls is higher in December-January.To protect the crop from frost effects, 0.1 percent quantity of sulfur acid, ie one liter sulfur acid should be sprayed in 1000 liters of water.  Smoke around the field is also beneficial if there is a possibility of frost.

Crop circle

The proper crop cycle has a special role to maintain the fertility of the land and to get more production from the crop.In non-irrigated area, crop-gram (one-year), fall-gram-fall-mustard (two-year), and fall-gram-fall-mustard-fall-gram (three-year) crop cycles can be adopted.

Seed production

The farmer can easily produce gram seeds on his farm.For the production of gram seeds, a field should be selected in which the gram crop was not grown last year.There should be proper drainage system in the field and gram crop should not be grown for 10 to 20 meters around the field.The sowing of the crop should be done at the appropriate time in a well prepared field.  Weeds should not remain in the ground and the land should be leveled by planting the ground.Sowing of certified seed or base seed should be done in rows.Before sowing, proper amount of manure and fertilizers should be used in the field.Periodic irrigation should be done in the field and timely control of weeds, pests and diseases.Undesirable and diseased plants should be removed before flowering in the field.After flowering, plants should be identified and removed on the basis of color and shape and branches in plants, on the properties of legumes such as length, color etc. in ripening stage.When the crop is fully ripened, that is, when the beans turn yellow and the grains become hard, the crop should be harvested after leaving the field 5 to 10 meters around the field.The harvested crop should be dried separately in a well-cleaned barn.When the crop dries properly, the grain should be separated from the straw by thrasher or beating it with a stick.Clean and dry the grains properly and when the moisture remains 8 to 9 percent, then healthy and good size grains should be graded.  Grading the grained grains by breaking the pesticide such as aluminum phosphide tablet or EDB ampule or by mixing at a rate of 250 g per quintal of malathion 5 per cent powder or fenvalrate powder and filling it in a metal casing, pucca cocci or Pusa cocci  Should be stored in a safe place, or stored in a new solution treated with one percent solution of malathione or decamethrin in a safe place.The seeds produced in this way can be used by the farmers for sowing next year.

Harvest and threshing

When the crop is ripe properly, harvesting should be done.When the leaves and beans become yellow and brown and the leaves start falling and the grains become hard, then the crop should be harvested.When the harvested crop dries properly, the grain must be separated from the straw by the thrasher and dried properly and stored in a safe place.

Yield and economic benefits

A crop grown using advanced techniques can yield 20 to 22 quintals of yield per hectare.  It costs about 15-20 thousand to grow a crop in one hectare area of gram.If the market price of gram is Rs 3000 per quintal, then a net profit of about Rs 25-30 thousand per hectare can be obtained.

link.title: Make more profit and deal with gram cultivation

entry.title: Farmers will get lottery due to cultivation of pigeonpea
entry.content:
har dal is also called Tuvar.  Adequate amounts of minerals, carbohydrates, iron, calcium etc.are found in it.It is an easily digested lentil, so it can be given to the patient as well, but it should be reduced to the patients of gas, constipation and breath.Its plants are not found in the forests.Its wild plants are found in the forests of Africa.On this basis, its place of origin is considered to be Africa.Probably this plant has been brought from Africa to Asia.Pulses are a cheap source of protein which the general public can also use in food, but its production in India is not according to the requirement.If the availability of protein is to increase, the production of pulses will have to be increased.  For this, developing species and their improved farming methods will have to be developed.Tur in the state is grown in an area of about 4.75 lakh hectares, producing an average yield of 842 kg per hectare.With the advanced technology, the production of pigeonpea can be doubled.


Land selection and preparation

It can be planted in a wide variety of lands, but light sandy loam or medium land with abundant spur and pH value between 7-8 and proper drainage is suitable for this crop.Medium duration or late ripening species should be sown in the area with deep land and adequate rainfall.Early maturing species should be sown in light sandy low sloping land and low rainfall area.  Make deep plowing of the field two or three times with a native plow or tractor and level the field by running the pata.Make proper drainage arrangements.

Sowing time, quantity and method of seed

Tax should be done with the commencement of the sowing of arhar.  Generally sow from the last week of June to the first week of July.  25-30 kg seeds per hectare in early maturing species and 15 to 20 kg seeds / hectare should be sown in medium maturing species.The distance between the queues is 30 to 45 cm for the early ripening and 60 to 75 cm for the medium and late ripening castes.should keep.Plant spacing of 10-15 cm for short duration castes.And 20 - 25 cm for the medium and late maturing species.Keep it

Seed treatment

Seed treatment with fungicide is very important before Bonnie.Treat 2 grams of thyroid + gram of Carbendazim fungicide according to seeds per kg of seeds.  Treat the treated seeds at the rate of 10 grams per kg of rhizobium culture.  Ph. D.  Use culture.

Election of castes

Depending on the type of land, time of sowing, climate etc., the castes of Arhar should be selected.Early maturing species should be sown in areas where irrigation facilities are available, multi-cropped cropping system or non-irrigated land with sandy slopes and low rainfall.  Medium duration casts should be sown in moderately deep land with sufficient rainfall and in irrigated and non-irrigated conditions.

Sowing time

Sowing of early maturing species should be done in the first fortnight of June and method and in medium fortnightly species in the second fortnight of June.The sowing should be in a row tied to the chonga behind the cedarial or plow.

Field preparation

It is advisable to do 2-3 tillage plows or harrows after deep plowing with a soil plow.After every plowing, it is necessary to provide adequate irrigation and drainage.

Fertilize

On the basis of soil testing, it is best to give all fertilizers at the depth of 2 cm from the surface of the seed and 5 cm from the seed surface in the back of the plow at the time of final plowing.  15-20 kg of nitrogen per hectare, 50 kg of phosphorus, 20 kg of potash and 20 kg of sulfur are required.In areas where there is a deficiency of zinc, use 15-20 kg of gink sulfate.Nitrogen and phosphorus are required in all lands.  But potash and zinc should be used only after soil conservation in the field.  A higher yield is obtained by using 100 kg of di ammonium phosphate and 100 kg of gypsum per hectare for the delivery of sulfur and phosphorus combined.

Seedling

To prevent soil borne diseases, sow the seeds by treating them at the rate of 2 grams of theram and 1 gram of carvendazim per gram or 3 grams of theram per gram.Seed treatment 2-3 days before seed treatment.

Irrigation and drainage

Since the crop is sown in unirrigated condition, irrigations should be done in the crop at the time of prolonged rains and during pre-flowering stage and grain formation.For high pigment production, proper drainage in the field is the first condition, so it is best to sow on the ridges in low and low drainage areas.

weed control

The presence of weeds in the field in the first 60 days is very harmful.  Increase in soil aeration with effective control of weeds 25-30 days after first sowing and second 45-60 days after harvesting two extracts from hand or khurpi creates favorable environment for growth of crop and co-bacteria.  .  But if there has been a serious problem of weeds in the field in the past years, then at the time of last plowing, the effective effect on the weeds by dissolving one kg of active quantity of vasalin in 800-1000 liters of water or spraying 3 kg of Lasso before seed germination.  Control can be found.

Crop Protection Methods

Insect control

Pomegranate / pulverized Qinal Fas or Indosulfan 35 EC, 20 ML / Qinalfas 25 EC 15 ML / Monocrotophos 30 W S C 11 11 ML per 10 liters of water should be sprayed and 1000 liter solution in one hectare should be used.

Leaf Wrap - Indosulfan 35EC 20 ML or Monocrotophos 36 WSC

Spray per mL of water per 10 liters.

Disease control

Phytrapthora blight - Sow seeds treated with Rhodomil 2g / kg seed.  Disease resistant species such as Asha, Maruthi BSMR-175 and VSMR-736 should be selected.Use built-resistant species, treat seeds and sow them.Solarize the soil.

Bandhymojac - Sow resistant species like Sharad, Bahar Asha, MA-3, Malviya Arhar-1 etc.Burn diseased plants.  Spray metastasic for control of carrier pests.

Pod butter

It makes a small round hole on the pod.Illi completes its life by eating grains within the pod and comes out as adult in the compost.The normal growth of the grains is halted.The crop is small and black in color, which makes planting eggs in growing beans.  Megats come out of the eggs and start eating the grains.Inside the pod, the megat transforms into a conch, causing a slant tunnel on the grain and the size of the grain remains small.  Completes one life cycle in three weeks.

Pod borer illy

The small ellipso eats the green tissues of the pods and when grown, causes damage to the buds, flower pods and seeds.Elliow makes crooked holes on pods.The female of this insect lays small white colored eggs.The cusp is yellow, green, black in color and has light patches on its body.Completes one life cycle in four weeks under favorable conditions.

Fall foul

The female usually lays eggs in bunch on the beans.Eggs are brown in color.  The baby adults of this insect suck the juice of both pods and grains, causing the pod to become oblique and the grains shrink.A life cycle is completed in about four weeks.

Plea Math

The caterpillar of this insect makes a small round hole on the pod.Its faith can be seen only near the outbreaks.  After some time, a red fungus develops around the infested Dano.

Bristle brittle

This beetle eats buds, flowers and soft beans, which reduces production significantly.The insect pests also cause damage on pigeonpea, urad, and other pulses.By catching and destroying the beetles, effective control is achieved.

1.Effective control of keto
2.At the time of agriculture
3.Deep plowing the field in summer
4.Do not sow pure pigeon
5.Adopt crop cycle
6.Should sow at the same time in the field
7.Use the recommended amount of chemical fertilizer.
8.International crops such as jowar, maize or peanut should be taken in tur.
9.By mechanical method
10.Crop crop should be applied
11.Install ferramine traps
12.Shake the plants and drop the crates and collect them and destroy them
13.Arrange for seating of birds in the field.
14.By biological control
15.NPV 5000 LE / ha.  + Uv  Sprinkle the retardant 0.1% + good 0.5% mixture in the evening in the field.
16.Spraying Bacillus thurangiensis 1 kg per hectare + Tinopal 0.1% + Good 0.5%.
17.By spraying bio-plant material

19.Neem oil or Karanja oil 10 - 15 ml.  + 1ml  Spraying of viscous substances (eg Sendovit Tipal) solution per liter of water.
20.Spray Nimbacidin 0.2% or Precise 0.5%.

By chemical control

Use pesticides only when necessary.

The pods should be sprayed with insecticidal insecticides such as dimethoate 30 EC 0.03 percent monocrotophos 36 S.L.  0.04 percent etc.

For control of pod borer caps

Fenvalerate 0.4 percent powder or Clinulphas 1.5 percent powder or Indosulfan 4 percent powder 20 to 25 kg / ha.Or indosulphon 35 EC.  0.7 percent or Quinalphos 25 E.C. 0.05 percent or Chloropyriphos 20 E.C.  0.6 percent or Fennelrate 20 EC 0.02 percent or Acetate 75 W P 0.0075 percent or Eleanicab 30 EC 500 grams per active ingredient per ha.Or Profenophos 50 EC per liter.Sprinkle with  For the control of both pests, first spraying should be done with all round insecticide and spraying of spray or all round insecticide at an interval of 10 days.Three pesticides or spraying of pesticide should be done at the first flowering stage, 50% at full flowering and third stage at pods.

Harvesting and mowing

When 80 percent of the beans are ripe, the crop should be harvested at a height of 10 cm from the Grasse or Hansea.After that, to make the crop dry, they make bundles and bring the crop to the barn.Then after drying for four to five days, pull the seeds out of the straw by pulman thresher or beating them on wooden logs.15-20 quintals per hectare of grain and 50-60 quintals of wood is obtained by cultivation under advanced method.

entry.title: You can earn from the cultivation of moong pulses
entry.content:
Green beads have a special crop of land and Southeast Asia. In this protein is found in very quantity. Apart from this, there are also carbohydrates, mineral elements and vitamins. Due to cooking in a short time it can be easily placed in the multifested cycle. After the brightness of the lands of the land, it works by pressing the soil in the field by turning the clay in the farm. By cultivating moong, the power of soil is also increased. Kharif, Rabi and Zayed can be easily grown in three seasons, in Northern India, it rises in rain and summer season, Moong in southern India grow in Rabi season, more rain is harmful for this crop, such The need for hot climate for the crop of the crop. This can be cultivated up to a height of 2000 meters from the sea level. While taking the beans on the plants and taking the beans, dry weather and high temperatures are very beneficial.


Soil

Moong is a pulse crop, which is prepared in less time. In both irrigation and irrigation irrigation, this can be cultivated easily. This has been considered to be profitable for the cultivation of good water with good drainage for farming. Red soil for good drainage with good drainage in northern India and red soil for southern India.

After the preparation of the farm 

After the start of the rain, there should be a collapse from the collapse or country solving by taking 1 to 3 times the solving in the field, and make the farm equal to the field. The farm should be removed from the farm and old crop. At the time of the last plowing, the dung or the compost manure should be found in the soil at the rate of 50 quintar per hectar. To rescue termite, Chloropearifas will be beneficial to mix the soil at the time of preparation of the farm at 15 percent of the powdered 20 kilogram per hectar.

Selection of moong species

4.Rabi and Kharif for both seasons- Type 44, PS 16, Pant Mong 1, Pusa Vishal, 851 and Shalimar Moong 

Quantity of seed 

12 to 15 kg seeds will be beneficial at the rate of 12 to 15 kg seeds and should be done at 30 to 40 centimeters in Bo queues. In Rabi and summer season, seed rate should be kept 20 kilogram per hectar and should be done at 20 to 25 centimeters in Bo queues.

Fertilizers and fertilizers 

Moong is a pulse crop, so it does not require much nitrogen, yet 20 kg nitrogen, 50 kg phosphorus and 20 kilograms of potat will be beneficial at the rate of hectar. In the lack of sulfur, the sulfilled fertilizer should be given according to 20 kilograms per hectare. If possible, in every third year, 1 time to 15 to 15 quintals should be used in the farm at the rate of hectare per hectare at the time of the last plowing.

Irrigation and water exhaust

Moong crop does not require irrigation in Kharif, but irrigation is greatly increased by irrigation in the condition of flowers. In the case of more rain, water is extremely necessary. Do not remove water, it becomes a disease, which has a huge loss to the crop. In the heat, there is a need for water than Kharif in the crop of the moong. In the summer season, 4 to 15 days should be 4 to 6 irrigation. If there is much heat, the difference of irrigation should be kept from 8 to 10 days.After 15 to 20 days of inside and weed control - 30 to 45 days after the first and 40 days should be made. To eliminate the weeds and wide leaf weed the chemical method, sprinkle 2 liters of Fluorilin 45 EC in the field before 800 to 1000 liters of water. Before the seed after the sowing, Pendimethylene 30 EC 3 Sprinkle 3 liters from 800 to 1000 liters of water and sprinkle at the rate of hectare.

Boi's time and way

Zayed Moong Bi, where irrigation facility should be done in February. In the Kharif season, Moong's boo should be between the first fortnight of June from June, the second fortnight of June. In Uttar Pradesh, Haryana, Delhi, Bihar and West Bengal are cultivated in the summer season. In these states, the moan sows after harvesting of sugarcane wheat, potato etc. Moong's sowing should be done in queues. The distance between 2 queues should be 30 to 45 centimeters. Seeds should be sown at a depth of 4 to 5 centimeters. Moong seeds should be sown only after treating carbandajim.

Black Lawy Must

In the case of getting pods from the new plant, this insect is found on the leaves of infant and adult plants. These sprayed crop sucks juice from soft twigs, flowers and raw beans.

Prevention

Protecting the property or crisoperala carnia, leaving 50000-100,000 eggs or hectares per hectare. Sprinkle Neem extracts 5 percent or 1.25 liters neem oil in 100 liters of water. BT should be sprayed at a rate of 1 kilogram per hectare. If there is no prevention in spite of this, then sprinkle metasystaces at 25 EC or Dipethot 30 EC or Imidaclop 17.8 SL or Thaomesam 25 EC 1 millimeters per liter.
